"Stories come in so many forms: in charcoal, and in song, in paintings, poems, films. And books."

This is a book about a girl, a boy, a devil, and the stories that get told and repeated and remembered. This is a tale of power dynamics and imbalances and what humans are willing to do to not feel trapped and alone. This is all about a young girl who lives her life for herself, who lives her life in spite of the odds, w

Oh, to be a French girl who knelt in the woods, on the eve of a wedding she did not want, and prayed for freedom to a god‚Äîor a devil?‚Äîwho only answers after the dark, and he made her a deal that will grow to be like a thorn in her, a goad: she will live forever, but she will be forgotten by everyone she meets, always slipping, like a thought, out of reach. An eternity of flitting from one place to another, never feeling quite at home anywhere, and fr

"And no matter how desperate or dire, never pray to the gods that answer after dark."

It's interesting. I read a couple of reviews for this book that said it was a slow-starter and took a hundred or so pages to get going, so I thought it was a good sign when I fell in love with it right away. The premise captivated me, drew me in, and took me away to another time and place; to an 18th century French village where young Adeline is being forced into a marriage she doesn't want. She prays so har

This time: I have no words for this masterpiece. Literally speechless, wordless, expressionless, blinking, sighing, awed, adored, fell hard, truly loved! I may announce you one of top ten best books of the year.

I know we‚Äôre at the fourth month and during our quarantine if I resume finishing approximately 10 to 14 books weekly, this means I can read nearly 500 more books but when you know, you know, this book is like unconditional love at first sight.

It‚Äôs a unique story about a village girl‚Äôs tr

‚ÄúWhat is a person, if not the marks they leave behind?‚Äù

Where do I start? This was a good book. What you'd expect from Victoria Schwab. Magical and lyrical. And yet...I turned the last page and was left wanting.

This is the book that Victoria has been working on for 10 years. And yes it's pretty. It's an amazing concept and an intriguing beginning. But I first read this in July and now, barely three months later, I cannot remember all that much except for the fact that Addie has seven bloody freck

IT'S OUT!!

Love story between a French girl and the devil over 300 years...

I tried to go into this book with low expectations considering romance isn't my genre and... Wow, this has to be V. E. Schwab's best book!

I've always liked her writing but this character-driven, slow-paced story really works for her. It's closer to literary fiction than her other work and her characters are much stronger.

Frankly, I recommend you go into it knowing nothing else.

Pick it up!

As I do my final read-through on this book, a story nearly 10 years in the making, all I can think is that I've put my heart and soul, my teeth and blood and bones into this one.

I hope you love it.

ETA: I can't believe we made it. Addie spent so many years haunting me, I hope she haunts a few of you. <3
oh SHIT

3.5 stars. VE Schwab has consistently great writing as always and really wrote her ass off here. I can tell many of the internal struggles that the main characters go through (particularly Henry) come from a personal place in Schwab's life, and you can feel that earnestly pouring through the pages. This book would be enjoyed by people who like slower, atmospheric, and character-driven stories. I think this works if you relate to the characters; if you don‚Äôt, the narrative becomes quite repetitiv

Adeline had wanted to be a tree.
To grow wild and deep, belong to no one but the ground beneath her feet, and the sky above, just like Estele. It would be an unconventional life, and perhaps a little lonely, but at least it would be hers. She would belong to no one but herself.




Day breaks like an egg yolk, spilling light across the field.




"Your freckles look like stars."
Addie smiles.

I know The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue will probably end up on a lot of people's favourite bookshelves this year, but having finished it, I can't say I'm in the same boat mostly due to the characterisation and emphasis on telling rather than showing.

With great regret I feel I must be a dissenting voice in on this book. I know I started out loving it, but as I delved deeper, the rest of the story didn‚Äôt materialize for me. I have always said that voice is the Big Kahuna of writing, it‚Äôs the ‚Äúeverything‚Äù of writing. This book has plenty of voice, and the character is real and three dimensional as well. These are two of the most difficult components to get right. The author did a wonderful job with them.

Her story will simply live on and continue to breathe, taking up space in my mind reserved for only the best of stories: the ones I carry with me like talismans where ever I go. Why I love it
by Alix E. Harrow

My favorite stories are the ones I‚Äôve heard before. Partly I blame my own obsessive personality for that‚ÄîI‚Äôve reread The Blue Sword a truly upsetting number of times‚Äîand partly I think it‚Äôs a deeper human thing. We like resonance and repetition; we like to shout under bridges just to hear the echoes.

The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue is unlike anything Victoria has ever written, yet its themes and writing style encapsulate the heart of what I've always loved most about her stories. Addie is a delightful slow burn which is something I've come to truly appreciate. I enjoyed both the journey and the destination. Addie gave me so much to ponder and I kept finding myself stopping so I could savor each line. The writing in this story is beautifully lyrical and repetitious in the way a catchy song

The Invisible Life of Addie Larue is a testament to the power of art and the inherently human desire of wanting to be remembered. This is by far the best written book V.E. Schwab has put into the world and you can really feel she has poured a lot of herself into this project.

Would you like to live for more than 300 years? After reading the experiences of Addie La Rue I know I would not.

Addie's life changes when she does a deal with a god and trades her soul for her freedom. She does not expect this to mean that no one will remember her. Once she leaves a room she is forgotten and each time she returns it is like the first time. Until one day, after hundreds of years of adapting herself to this, someone does remember her.

Addie LaRue did what she was always taught not to. First, she allowed herself to dream and in these dreams she was free and belonged to no man. Second, she made a deal with the things that haunt the moonlit hours. The one led from the other and now Addie is a free thing but also a cursed one. She enjoys immortality and is tethered to no other human, but is doomed to be forgotten by all at the very moment she is rem

What she needs are stories.
Stories are a way to preserve one's self. To be remembered. And to forget.
Stories come in so many forms: in charcoal, and in song, in paintings, poems, films. And books.
Books, she has found, are a way to live a thousand lives‚Äîor to find strength in a very long one.

The Once and Future Witches is unapologetically feminist, chock-full-of-witches and sisterly: there's sapphic pining, books, reworked feminist fairytales and women in every form, fighting the patriarchy. Told in beautiful prose from the perspective of the three Eastwood sisters: a librarian, a mother-to-be and a revengeful teenager, it's a powerful and timely tale about fighting for your seat at the table, even when it burns.

2.5 stars. I expected to like this one so much that I almost bought it new, unread, in hardback. I'm relieved I didn't, and crushed that I'm relieved. It's not the writing - Alix Harrow writes gorgeous prose that is both smooth and chewy, rhythmic and immersive. It's not the subject - turn of the century Salem full of suffragettes and witchcraft, studded with altered fairy tales, mythology, and nursery rhymes. But somehow, The Once and Future Witches ends up being less than the sum of its parts.

"Must a thing be bound and shelved in order to matter? Some stories were never written down. Some stories were passed by whisper and song, mother to daughter to sister."

Harrow blew my mind with her short story "A Witch‚Äôs Guide to Escape" - and this very much feels like a spiritual successor. review_text:
Loved it! üß°üß°üß°

As I finish The Once and Future Witches, I find myself tucked in neatly in a circle of salt, not wanting to dare the world around it. With the scintillating aromas of woods and potions, enraptured in spells and bindings, I have found my calling long hidden in the folktales of my youth. Witches are real. They are still among us hidden in the codex of stories, humming their powers till the day for a reawakening marks their full return.

Harrow has done a marvelous job connecting fiction

'The wayward sisters, hand in hand,
Burned and bound, our stolen crown,
But what is lost that can't be found?'

The Once and Future Witches is a historical fantasy set in 1893, New Salem, where the ways of witching are near extinct thanks to the purging of magic in Old Salem in the 1600s. The novel follows three sisters: Beatrice Belladonna 'the wise sister, quiet and clever as an owl in the rafters', Agnes Amaranth 'the strong sister, steady as a stone and twice as hard' and James Jun

I was so excited to receive a copy of The Once and future witches by Alix E Harrow. After reading her first novel The Thousand Doors of January which blew my mind, I couldn‚Äôt wait to dive in.
It‚Äôs 1893 in New Salem North America there are three Eastwood sisters Agnes, Bella and James Juniper. They lived in a world that there once was witches but now is it forbidden. There tales and the spells are a now passed down from mother to daughter through fairy tales and books. It is also the time of the s

Witches, suffragettes, and Alix E. Harrow are all the ingredients needed for the fantastical feminist read we all deserve! And I guess all my wishes just came true, as I got approved for an arc of it!

‚ÄúThey keep burning us. We keep rising again.‚Äù

In 1893 witching is simply charms and spells made from nursery rhymes. Women are working in the factories and in their homes and some are fighting for their right to vote.
When the three Eastwood sisters - Bella, Agnes, and Juniper - are brought together in New Salem after seven years apart, they find the power they had only heard of in whispers and words passed down from mother to child. A tower appears in the town square - forgotten words have been s

This review can also be found on my blog The Tattooed Book Geek: https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress...

The Once and Future Witches sees the three Eastwood sisters, Agnes Amaranth, Beatrice Belladonna and James Juniper stitch together the wounds of the past, reconcile their fractured relationship, break the chains, cast off the shackles of servitude, rise up and readdress the balance of power, bring witchcraft back into the world and wage war on oppression taking up the fight for women‚Äôs and wi

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all magic is, really: the space between what you have and what you need.‚Äù

We are all witches.

In The Once and Future Witches, Harrow argues that we have the means to tap into a reservoir of power to achieve wonderous and needful things. All that witchery requires are the words of execution, the ways of planning, and an unshakable will to bridge the gap between what you have and taking what you deserve.

Witchery has two histories. There are the centuries-old witch stories that have become c

The Once and Future Witches, Alix E. Harrow‚Äôs sophomore novel set in the late 1800s, is the story of three witch sisters fighting for the power to vote in an alternate history America during the suffrage movement and is very much a powerful and contemporary feminist fairytale. It is both a love letter to folkloric traditions and an ode to the fierce power rebellious women throughout history have wielded. There‚Äôs no such thing as witches, but there used to be. It used to be the air was so thick w

4.75 stars

Once and Future Witches feels like the book of my soul. This book captures that hidden wild spark inside all our souls that longs for otherness and power. The writing is so atmospheric and lyrical, it feels like having a cup of tea outside in the autumn in a garden full of herbs and falling leaves. The witchy aspexts of this book really spoke to me as well, I'm fascinated by the whole idea of crafting power from words and herbs and this book just felt so magical.

This was such a strange and wonderful book. It just had so many elements that really worked for me. A bunch of sapphic characters, dark things happening at an all girls boarding school, storylines that play out in different timelines, a mix of horror and comedy, and a fun meta aspect. The story was so atmospheric, there were some genuinely creepy moments that made my skin crawl. And even though the tone would switch back and forth between gothic horror and meta comedy, it always felt organic. It

This was utterly lovely. It's a big book, but it doesn't necessarily feel like it is (although the story is layered and rich). Danforth created a set of interesting characters that felt very real and that I could sympathise with even at moments when I found them unlikeable (although Alex will always have my heart). Also, this book might very well be the queerest thing I have ever read, which in itself should be enough to recommend it.

1.5 stars!
This novel follows three storylines that are all connected to one place: the Brookhants School for Girls. Located off the coast of Rhode Island, it‚Äôs hauntingly beautiful and mysterious. In 1902, three of the students die after forming the ‚ÄúPlain Bad Heroines‚Äù society after they form friendships based around a book given to them by their headmistress. Fast forward to the future where a horror movie is being filmed on location about the three girls and their demise. Harper Harper, Audre

[4.25/5] Plain Bad Heroines flows back and forth between past and present. The past takes us to Brookhants School for Girls in the early 1900s, where two young girls mysteriously die and strange happenings continue to occur long after. In the present, we follow three modern women, all involved in the making of a movie covering the haunted history of Brookhants.

It‚Äôs important to note that this book is long: about 600 pages in total. When you first start reading, it takes a moment to settle into t

A creepy story so sweet that it leans into rot, as fallen apples bursting in the late summer heat. Like a songwriter, Danforth carefully chooses four or five notes to create terror, starts by playing only one or two at a time, and rearranges them into different melodies before reaching a caterwauling crescendo.

Memorable, complicated characters and a truly terrifying setting make this one that will stick with you.

This book had so much promise!! I really loved the premise, the characters, the theme and gothic vibe but it felt flat to me. The story jumps back and forth from past to present and both stories were so intriguing that I wanted more. This would have been better divided into 2 books. The writing and unique perspective is the reason I gave it 3 stars.

Plain Bad Heroines was such a unique book with a really great storyline. This book is a story within a story within a story lol. I loved peeling back the layers to this one and diving deep into this setting.

This was a fantastically fun book to read in New England in October, and it was, as promised, thoroughly gay, though it certainly wasn't as spooky as the press would lead you to believe. It's definitely got that pop-gothic sensibility that's so in right now, but the ghost story itself is pretty convoluted and ethereal; it's much more of a generalized aesthetic than an actual plot element. There's plenty of dread that doesn't really manifest into much of anything. I still had fun reading it, thou

Plain Bad Heroines is turn of the century queer boarding school horror and then some. It is not just a book within a book. It is a book about a book about a book. No wait. It's about a movie about a book within a book. And did I mention someone in the book is writing a book about the movie about a book about a book? Anyway, I think you get it. Well-written and intricately plotted, this book, through no fault of it's own, buzzes a few of my pet peeves right off the bat - multiple POVs and long-(long, long)-game plots. I really only feel invested in the three present-day girls, and the overarching sense of dread on their behalf makes it really hard to pick up the book.

I'm also not really finding that there's a good balance between

This gothic tale is not a book you want to enter into lightly. Make sure your schedule is clear and you will want to give your full attention to Plain Bad Heroines by Emily M. Danforth. I thoroughly enjoyed it, but I really did need to concentrate. There were footnotes, sly comments, and metafiction to keep your mind engaged. And the gorgeous illustrations throughout by Sara Lautman added another wonderful element to Plain Bad Heroines.

This was a slow read for me, but the story pace wasn‚Äôt slow.

Plain Bad Heroines is capital-G Gothic with some good spooky vibes. The narration is cool, and the actual craft of the novel is interesting. I'm definitely questioning some of the choices that were made, though. The structure wasn't always totally effective, and did that many queer women have to die in one book? Still, I think plenty of readers will enjoy this book.

OMG so good. This is a long ass book to really sink your teeth into - a creepy, queer, absorbing metafiction about a haunted boarding school. Dual narratives - one in the early 1900s at the Rhode Island boarding school and one in modern day Hollywood - weave in and out, piecing together a creepy story of forbidden love, unjust consequences, and strong ladies getting revenge. This was a book I didn't want to end (and that's saying a lot because I love finishing books).

Do you like books about cursed boarding schools? Gothic? Giant? Funny? Queer positive? Meta? Ultra ooky spooky? Blurbed by Sarah Waters?
Then, you should most definitely read this book when it comes out. I loved this book! It has absolutely everything in it.

An incredibly satisfying book, hitting many of my wheelhouses. Part historical novel, part contemporary filmmaking novel, and all LGBTQ fiction. Both narratives were engrossing and fed off each other well, telling parallel tales of the lives of queer women at the beginning of the 20th century and today. 2020 has had some real highs and some real lows as far as my reads have gone, but this is definitely one of my top picks of the year. Queer horror! With one (or two?) of the timelines being in a historical queer gothic style, I know there will be comparisons to Sarah Waters. But the contemporary storyline,

After 200 glacial paced pages, we were no deeper into the stories or the characters, and the narrator's clever asides to the reader were starting to grate on me. Just not for me, unfortunately.
You had me at New England and boarding schools.

Are you looking for a super scary read for Halloween?

Yes? Then look elsewhere.

Because T. Kingfisher‚Äôs newest horror novel, The Hollow Places, isn‚Äôt really a horror novel. And it‚Äôs not super scary.

It‚Äôs a fantasy. More accurately, it‚Äôs a humorous fantasy, with occasional moments of creepy, squirmy Weird/Lovecraftian horror. (And I do mean, occasional. The moments are very few and far between.)

But it works.

The Hollow Places is a super WEIRD, extremely well-written Horror story penned in Kingfisher's signature quirky style.

I think it's really hard to nail weird, yet she does it.



The humor and heart brought to her stories is so refreshing to read.

If you haven't read anything by Kingfisher yet, this would be a great place to start.

The Hollow Places is the latest supernatural horror novel from the inimitable Ursula Vernon, under the nom de plume T. Kingfisher. Newly divorced and perturbed by the prospect of having to move back in with her parents, 34-year-old graphic artist Kara (aka Carrot) returns to where she spent her formative years, picturesque Hog Chapel, North Carolina, and gladly accepts her eccentric Uncle Earl‚Äôs offer of inhabiting a spare room in Glory to God Museum of Natural Wonders, Curiosities and Taxidermy

THE HOLLOW PLACES BY: T. KINGFISHER I think this book will stay with me for awhile, I'm afraid the willows have taken root. I know many people draw the obvious parallels with Lovecraft, but for me this one also had some vibes that brought up touchstones from The Mist (Stephen King) and a smidge of Pan's Labyrinth. Definitely that dark otherworldliness but also the religious and/or mythical undertones throughout.
 
Sometimes the vastness and imagination that goes into multiverses can be overwhelmin

The story itself is smaller and more contained with only three main characters, but what the two of them discover hiding behind the wall of the third‚Äôs place of business is pretty epic. The shop is a marvel of oddities, from an albino stuffed raccoon to a mermaid.

Recently divorced, living back home with her parents, and working at her uncle's glorified curiosity shop - the Wonder Museum - nothing much seems like it would shake up Kara, our unflappable narrator. That is until one day after the tourists have left the museum and Kara finds that a hole has been punched in a back wall of the building. A hole that leads to a bunker.

After her marriage ends in divorce, Kara moves into her uncle's museum of oddities and antiquities. While struggling with her grief, Kara tackles the immense task of cataloging all the items in the museum - who can't relate to taking on a disaster when in such personal pain? She insists her uncle undergo knee surgery and assumes responsibility. While managing along, Kara forms a friendship with Simon, the barrister of the coffeeshop also housed in her uncle's building.

I devoured this book pretty much in one sitting, and it was absolutely worth it.

This series is so complex, and there are so many subtle details to the narration (not to mention so many different narrators), that it's hard to imagine a final book could possibly wrap it all up in a satisfying way. Especially when you consider how many eagerly awaited finales of the past few years have ended badly and left fans devastated and furious.

I didn't really expect MWT to blow the landing on her own series

I wish for this to be longer; it could have been doled out as several more lengthy novels, right? Not that it was damn near perfect as is, tying so many stories and characters and political schemes together with subtle precision. I even cried for a character I despised. I also wish for there to be several more books coming. I don‚Äôt want it to be over. Despite that bittersweet realization, I loved being privy to this world and these characters and I sense several more re-reads of them all in the

This has been an amazing ride. I can't recommend this series highly enough.

Potentially the best thing MWT has ever written.

A stunning conclusion to one of my favorite series of all time.

Eugenides' story began as the tale of a simple thief, way back in the first book‚Äîa tale that became vastly more complicated than at first it seemed, but only after carefully-constructed and absolutely-unpredictable plot twists that made it necessary to stop and rethink everything. Somehow, Turner has managed to keep that level of unpredictability, of narrative awe, of delightful twists and turns that are always 100% in character, th

I generally find conclusions to be something of a letdown, but this was wildly entertaining. Narrated by a fascinating new character, this story is full of intrigue, gloriously cinematic scenes, perfectly crafted dialogue, poignant twists, and laugh-out-loud humor. And the coda is breathtaking and so, so lovely. I tried to read as deliberately and slowly as I could and I'm sure I still missed at least half of what was actually going on -- but the magic of Turner's books is that they're incredibl

My book didn't arrive until this past Monday, and I just finished it last night. It's never been so hard to go back to work.

Bittersweet to finish this. I can't imagine experiencing the headiness of being so involved in a series ever again, and it happened during really formative years of my life. I know we were all dying to know how the story ends, but my overall feeling is something like grief/mourning/sadness...it was never so fun to wait for books as it was with this series and the fandom.
Man it's just a neat, lovely, wonderful ending!! I was so convinced it was all gonna end tragically, not sure why haha. This was perfect. So much shenanigans!!

Endings are hard things to get right, and this book is an ending 20 years in the making. MWT's fans have read and re-read the books before this one in the series many, many times (I can personally attest to that), so expectations were bound to be high. That that were met, and even exceeded, is a tremendous testament to MWT's superb skill with plot, character development, and world

After a long delay, we get the end to the saga of the Thief. This book is much like my favorite third one, showing us Gen and the court from the POV of an outsider, but larger in scope, as the war with the Medes looms near. If I'd had the patience, I'd have reread the series (again) first - there are a ton of secondary characters, and I'd lost track of a few (although the book does have a glossary.)

But I couldn't wait to see more of one of my all-time favorite characters, and this was a treat.

I got the new Megan Whalen Turner book--the last in the Queen's
Thief series--Return of the Thief. I am about half finished and it is reminding me of what I love about her books and what pisses me off about them. She annoys me somehow. But every time I want to throw one across the room she wins me back, over and over and over again. I think she makes me work too hard for too little. I end up feeling tantalized but never sated. She teases me with little crumbs of things I love about her great cha

This series is near and dear to my heart. I read the first book over a decade ago. Every few years, Megan Whalen Turner has blessed us with a new book and this is the final book in the series. It was every bit as wonderful as the other stories.

The author is a master at telling a character‚Äôs story through someone else‚Äôs eyes. This final instalment was precious and beautifully told. I love it so much!

When picking up the final book in a series that means a lot to you, there comes feelings of excitement, hesitation and dread. What if it isn‚Äôt a fitting conclusion? What if your favourite character(s) dies? What if the final book ruins all the ones before it?

It is. My lips are sealed. It doesn‚Äôt.

Listen, this series was always going to be top tier for its impressive use of mythology, detailed world-building, and incredibly memorable characters and I think Megan Whalen Turner stuck the landing here. This book doesn't just exist to tie plots and machinations together quite neatly but also add layers upon layers of complexity to these characters and this world. There's something sweet and meaningful about characters dealing with disability and intergenerational trauma with compassion and em
What a good series.
My heart is at peace.
Full review to come.

We are kings and queens, not all-powerful gods. We cannot reward the good men and punish the bad ones just as we would prefer.

The Queen's Thief series is one of the Fantasy book series that been here for a long time already that may be unknown to the new fantasy readers in our generation and maybe

If you are one of the many who waited in patience for the book, feel reassured and prepared to delve deep into the Little Peninsula we all longed to revisit.

The book takes a surprising turn in the storytelling pov, but an all the same welcome one from almost all the books past, and in this version we are invited ever deeper into the ongoing of the machinations of Gen as Annux and the two queens and other king of the Little Peninsula as they fight the threats that encroach.

The story is riveting

Received and read my copy yesterday! I have been looking forward to this for years and also dreading that it might be a letdown. It is not a letdown. It's everything I could have hoped for. I've struggled a bit with the new narrator in each book, wanting more direct access to Gen's actions and thoughts, but I adore the narrator, Pheris, the Baron Erondites' supposed heir, sent to be one of the King's attendants on Eugenides' orders. While Pheris is technically the heir, he was born with a geneti

Would it even be possible for me to give a Queen's Thief book less than 5 stars? This is the final book in a series that I've been reading since elementary school, since before I could truly appreciate MWT's genius, since before I knew it would be anything beyond the first book. It's my favorite series ever and I don't think I'll ever find anything better, and I'm ok with that. I was a little worried, going into this book, that the ending would be either too sappy or too depressing for my taste,

It has been a long time since I have so thoroughly loved a book like I have loved this one.

In this book we see every story Turner has told brought together, every character we have come to so desperately love brought to their well-deserved rest.

Never, I think, have I loved Eugenides more than in this book. I learned his character in The Thief, I came to appreciate his cleverness and tenacity in The Queen, and I loved him for all his ruthlessness and compassion in The King. All of those character

Can‚Äôt say that the plot‚Äôs all that fresh‚Äî‚ÄúThe Medes try again!‚Äù‚Äîbut it gives the author lots of chances to play to her strengths in exploring nuances in characters and relationships...as, for instance:

‚ÄúHelen, you know how it will go. They will agree, like people always do, that it‚Äôs all my fault.‚Äù He shifted painfully again. Not finding a better spot, he gave up with a sigh. ‚ÄúThey are adults. They know what is at stake. They will sit next to each other on a bench without speaking until the palac

Sometimes, you think a book has nothing else to say to you after the Nth reread.
sometimes, you are sad a series is finished, because somehow they always tend to disappoint in some way - some only because you are reaching the end.

but then there is this series and this book. And I know I missed something, I missed a reference or a nuance, I didn't spot something quite innocuous happening in the first, second, third fourth or fifth book.

I know that when I will reread this whole series, be it a mont

How do you review a book where every word is perfect, (almost) every character beloved, and the events play out in a way that leaves you with no complaints or criticisms?

And a book which you know will be even more delightful on a reread, to find what you missed, to see humor and meaning in what the characters knew before you did, to uncover even more connections to the previous books, or merely to spend time with these phenomenal characters?

The Queen's Thief books are works of art. Read them, i

The countries of the Little Peninsula are united against the Mede Empire, but for how long? The truth of what happened during the first few years of Eugenides' rule as annux, told by the disabled grandson of the troublesome Attolian baron Erondites. I'm astounded at how many plots, characters, and themes the author managed to weave together over the course of this series, and how well they all resolved.

I will miss these characters, especially Gen, something terrible.

Luckily, I was able to get a copy from a bookstore a few days before release. Huzzah! (view spoiler)I'm ultimately pleased with this final book, and I can't wait to reread in order to pore over the details. It was worth the wait. :)

Oh, wow! I cannot believe Megan Whalen Turner's ability to both satisfy and surprise us. I'm sure I'm not alone in wanting to know more about that small, silent child at the end of Thick as Thieves. Not only does Megan tell us more--he's the narrator! AND he's disabled/differently abled, which I would not have guessed. And his voice--looking back as an adult on events he did not fully understand at the time--is so, so well-done. I absolutely loved little Pheris, who also broke my heart a little.

This is a fantastic wrap-up to the series. It's split into two "books", the first is much more similar in style and scope to the previous books, the second half is more keyed into wrapping up the whole series, though the two halves are still unified. From the start, P. Djeli Clark's RING SHOUT explodes into vivid color with a voice that's at once joyous and harrowing. Maryse is a stunning character, real and layered, and brilliantly employed in a novella that is confident, razor sharp, and utterly imaginative. An instant favorite.

Ring Shout is a weird and smart little novella that blurs the lines between historical fantasy and horror. It follows a group of Black women in the 1920's who hunt evil KKK members, but with a twist. This is a fascinating story that serves to frame very real history through a fantastical lens that perhaps allows for a different approach to insight. It has impressively deep worldbuilding and well-developed characters despite the length.

The cover and synopsis of Ring Shout drew me to this book. This historical science fiction novella is about three Black women from 1920s Georgia (Maryse, Sadie, and Chef) who are bootleggers and hunters of monsters known as Ku Kluxes. Ku Kluxes are people who turned into monsters when hate infected their bodies. This book is a good social commentary on the effect that hate has on the perpetrators and theirs victims. I have had P. Djeli Clark on my radar for a while now, with him releasing various novellas through Tor.com. After reading the premise of this one, I had to give it a whirl. He knocked it out of the park.

Thanks to NetGalley for this audiobook. The narrator of this dark fantasy was incredible. The story is character driven and I loved Maryse and her magic sword. Sadie was an extremely likeable character.

This is a story about monsters. Otherworldly beings and those who walk amongst us. The Klu Kluxes are pure hatred and evil personified as shape shifting monsters - and only a small band of female warriors can see them for what they really are.

This is a tale of vengeance and injustice, gore and terror and ultimately love and hope. I loved reading about Maryse and her band of strong women, and really enjoyed how African myth and history was incorporated into this story. It was a great adventure.

RING SHOUT by P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark is one of the best books of 2020. It is so unique and downright spectacular. Tor continues to impress me with their novellas.

The story takes place in Macon, Georgia, during the 1920s Prohibition. G.W. Griffith releases a film called Birth of a Nation, and when Ku Klux Klan members view it, they become evil demons called Ku Kluxes. Our main protagonist, twenty-five-year-old Maryse Boudreaux, is aware of this and takes action along with help from her allies, the resist

Overall, this is without a doubt one of my favorite books of 2020. I think my new favorite sub-genre is the specific "Lovecraftian horror, but intentionally and completely rejects/subverts the racist overtones of Lovecraft's writing by using the inter-dimensional monsters as a tool to write a story about fighting for justice and equity" (Also in this vein would be The City We Became by N. K. Jemisin)

As for the story, what's relevant in the US in 1922 is still relevant 98 years later. Clark perfe

From Dead Djinn, to Tram Car 015, and now Ring Shout, Clark manages to make his worlds as familiar as they are rich and vividly imaginative. His settings become places I've been before. His characters are people I know. His magic is something I've witnessed or wielded in tangible memories. RING SHOUT is no different. Here, he's found the only way to write about the Klan that doesn't give me violent, ancestral fits. A feat, all things considered.

"It takes two heartbeats for them fix on me. Then they‚Äôre galloping on all fours, snarling and marking me as prey. But like I said already, I hunt monsters. And I got a sword that sings."

I've said it once and I'll say it again: P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark is one of the best SFF writers out there right now. He is a master of plot, and worldbuilding, often creating whole universes in a short story or novella. Clark also gives us the stories and characters we've longed to see in SFF for so long: from Egyptian detectives in A Dead Djinn in Cairo to Orisha-possessed heroines in The Black God's Drums. He does it yet again in

The novella perfectly captures the inner voice of a young southern black woman living in 1922 with its rhythm and slang. The informal writing style allowed me to get a real sense of the main character's personality.

The protagonist is a demon hunter who slays Ku Kluxes, monsters who are born from hate. She wields a sword whose powers comes from the misery of past slaves. The descriptions of the monsters were gruesome and horrifying! A white tree with a fleshy interior. A body covered with mouths

This has a lot of what I love about Clark‚Äôs work but is definitely a new and different direction. The wonderful characters are there and the rich and fully developed world is also there, but it is more weird and serious and less charming than his other work. Not worse. Just different. Recommended for people who liked The City We Became, Riot Baby, or any of Victor Lavalle.

This book is written so tightly it feels as if not a single word is wasted. Maryse takes us on a journey to the south and along the way teaches us the folk tales that give her power. This story is about the power of hate in a fantastical world that looks like our own USA. The hate in our world is real and this book can teach us something about how to fight it.

Excellent. Strong depth of character and world building within a shorter novella format. Really enjoy books that don't cater to a white audience and just says here is the world, sink or swim. The use of Gullah without providing translations or, in a lot of cases even supporting contextual dialogue, is just brilliant.

Killer. I was a fan of Clark's work from THE BLACK GOD'S GUNS and "A Dead Djinn in Cairo" -- but this surpasses just about anything else he's written thus far. A dark fantasy read with current social commentary. Taking place in Macon, Georgia during the Prohibition Era. Ku Klux Klan members see a movie called Birth of a nation, they become evil demons called Ku Kluxes. Maryse Boudreaux and her resistance fighters, Sadie and Chef are sent to kill the Ku Kluxes to save the world. It has action, suspense, historical fiction and horror. It‚Äôs a novella that packs an impactful punch.

Okay, truly, ANYTHING written by Clark is frikkin amazing (I believe I have, in the past, waxed poetic about both The Black God's Drums and The Haunting of Tram Car 015) but, Ring Shout is something completely different. Maryse, a woman with a lot of anger, a lot of love, and a magic sword, has to face the demons created by hatred--not just external demons, but the ones in her head, too. Not for the squeamish (there are a lot of mouths and...fleshy bits. A lot of body horror, basically.) but abs

Ring Shout is a stark, perfectly blunt piece of speculative fiction that is sure to make you shudder and *gasp* from all of the body horror while drawing you into the magical and fantastically weaved world by Clark. Clark completely masters taking a moment in time, and sculpting it into something so unbelievably real that it is horrifying- and you don‚Äôt want to look away. Expertly mixing unnerving fiction with true historical events and timelines, Clark delivers a gut punch in under 200 pages. I

Ring Shout is an experience. It reads like a surreal fever dream in some parts and alternative history all at once. With elements of horror, dark fantasy, and history, Clark insures that readers of all kinds will enjoy this read.

To justify how movements of hate in human history can involve so many people, a label of 'monstrosity' is often attributed to their nature--and in Ring Shout, P. Dj√®l√≠ Clark makes that monstrosity literal in a fantastical setting of a post-world-war Southern United States, where senseless hate invokes the attention of the purest evil, and connections to ancestral roots manifest in magic and spiritual power.

Maryse is the quintessential magical hero; as some kind of knight for a larger cause, she

In a world where white supremacists are sorcerers and the Klu Klux Klan are actual interdimensional demonic monsters who feed off of hate, only one can save us. Maryse is this chosen one. We follow Maryse hunt and slaughter these literal monsters with her rag-tag team of monster hunters: a World War I veteran who had to disguise herself as a man to fight, a dreamy sharpshooter that never misses a shot, an overeager scientist, a character who likes to push everyone‚Äôs buttons by talking about soci

In the vein of Matt Ruff‚Äôs Lovecraft Country, which I also read this year and loved, Clark‚Äôs book expertly melds Lovecraftian horror with the everyday horror of history. As the book begins, it‚Äôs only about a year out from the Tulsa Massacre, which you may have seen depicted on Watchmen. If you didn‚Äôt, then the briefest explanation is that a group flattened Tulsa‚Äôs prosperous Black community basically because they could.

I could be fanciful and call them a group of monsters or something like that.

Lightbringer by Claire Legrand is the 3rd and final book in her Empirium trilogy. I waited with high anticipation for this final book of this trilogy, and am happy to say that LeGrand did a masterful job of ending this to our satisfaction. Refresher: The theme of this trilogy revolves around two heroines, Rielle and her daughter, Eliana; one destined to be the Blood Queen (who would destroy the world) and the other to be the Sun Queen (who is the Queen of Light and Salvation).

Everyone has the capability to do magic (which is here based on rituals and spirit possession), but only men are allowed to become fully-fledged magicians. Due to the risk spirits would pose to fetuses, women are only allowed a rudimentary magical education and upon marrying they are forced to wear collars that dampen their magical gift.

Beatrice Clayborn is a sorceress who practices magic in secret, terrified of the day she will be locked into a marital collar that will cut off her powers to protect her unborn children. She dreams of becoming a full-fledged Magus and pursuing magic as her calling as men do, but her family has staked everything to equip her for Bargaining Season, when young men and women of means descend upon the city to negotiate the best marriages. The Clayborns are in severe debt, and only she can save them,

"The current system lays all of the restriction, all the responsibility, and all the burden on sorceresses. Men aren't inconvenienced in any way. They may do whatever they like. For them, the system isn't broken, so why look for a solution?"

A truly delightful Regency-inspired romance that packs a feminist punch.

Beatrice Clayborn is embarking on her very first bargaining season, and she must secure herself a wealthy husband in order to raise her family out of debt. But in Chasland, marriage for a sorceress means losing one's magical powers - women are forced into warding collars on their wedding day to protect future offspring from spirit possession during pregnancy.

This book was well written and had some interesting world building. The book is set in a world that has small magic abilities for most people but to become a Mage and operate higher magics you have to bind a spirit to your soul. Women are not allowed this higher binding. To ensure this, they are married off young and then bound by a metal collar that takes magic away from the bearer. They wear this collar until they are no longer of child bearing age.


There was something that held me slightly ba

For women, options for the future are limited, and Beatrice wants more out of life. Mainly, she wants to keep practicing magic. Why can‚Äôt she become a mage like men? However, it did not connect with the story nor the characters. I expected something a bit different, more action-packed I never felt invested in what was going on whatsoever. I felt it lacked depth and mystery and I found it hard to care. It is hard to express how I feel, I didn't like it but I didn't not like it.

This was well written and had some really compelling characters. But I was a bit disappointed in the plot/setting - I was excited to read something set in the French Revolution, but the bulk of the book was set in England. And the plot was a lot about ownership of self, which I didn't anticipate, as well as the science of making the philosopher's stone. I don't blame the book so much as the way the book is being pitched and what those pitches lead me to expect.

*This is an almost spoiler-free review. It is all safe apart from my second complaint which has been hidden for those who haven't yet read the book.*

This novella is not only chock full of interesting plotlines and great character work, but it also contains within it so much more than I was expecting in terms of both lore, world building and references to (and straight up knowledge of) the wider Cosmere.
I was captivated enough to read Dawnshard in a single day and it was generous with it's length

Dawnshard is another illuminating and beautifully crafted piece in the Cosmere puzzle.

Every time a new Stormlight Archive story gets released my excitement goes through the roof. There is no reading I enjoy more, and I am so thankful that I am lucky enough to be getting not only one, but two new Cosmere stories this year!

Dawnshard is a novella, and as such shorter than your average SA book, but it‚Äôs still longer than Brandon planned and comes in at about 200 pages. Let me tell you though, I

As soon as I got access to Dawnshard through the Kickstarter, I immediately started reading. Dawnshard is an incredible and intricately woven story that stands alone while also expanding the Cosmere in significant ways.

Dawnshard mostly follow Rysn with The Lopen sprinkled throughout. When the perspectives for the novella were first announced, I was slightly disappointed since The Lopen isn‚Äôt my favourite character. I find him to be slightly annoying at times. The amount I see him in the main se

Cosmere fans, you're in for such a treat because I was not expecting such a stunning revelation. But not only do we get loads of lore and Cosmere connections in this, the character development of these two side characters from the main series was fantastic! And there's excellent representation of those who are disabled or people who are 'different'. Brilliant empathetic writing all round without sacrificing plot, pace and worldbuilding.

Full RTC.

Between Mistborn: Secret History, Edgedancer, and now Dawnshard, these shorter novellas really allow Sanderson to flex the (constantly twitching) "side-story muscle" that is so clearly difficult for him to manage in the main series. That's not a criticism of his authorship either - the simultaneous depth and breadth of ideas floating around in his head is one of the things that makes his writing so great. But I personally find

I admit that the interludes in The Stormlight Archive are my weakest knowledge points in the entire series. They're the parts that are easiest to gloss over and (more often than not) give a feel for tone or world than they do for any sort of... plot. I will also admit that shorter fiction has never been something I'm particularly drawn to.

But one of the strengths of The Stormlight Archive is its ability to surprise, to accelerate far, far faster than I imagined. The Way of Kings is easily my fav

3.5 stars **Although this is a spoiler-free review (spoilers are hidden), there may be spoilers for previous books in series**

First off, you're in for a ride... physically and metaphorically. In this latest Cosmere novella, we follow Rysn and Lopen as they are sent on an expedition to Akinah after the ship that carried those unfortunate sailors and Soulcaster (that we saw in an Oathbringer Interlude) to their deaths... On the voyage, various "bad omens from the Gods" occur that dissuade the ship

Because writing 1200+ page books every three years alongside smaller YA books isn‚Äôt enough, Brandon Sanderson has also decided to write novellas for the Stormlight Archives. This most recent novella, Dawnshard, (which is really a short novel, but who‚Äôs counting) was included as part of the kickstarter of The Way of Kings leatherbounds and I was able to get my ebook copy just a couple days ago.

The story follows Rysn, the Thaylen trader with a brand new ship, and the Lopen, former one-armed Herdaz

This is a fun little story, but it feels not only incredibly rushed but also woefully unoriginal. It feels a bit like a teaser. Not a teaser for Rhythm of War, but a teaser for the Stormlight Archive in general (although there would be some spoilers if you read it before The Way of Kings, spoilers you might not even realize are there). Something that makes you curious about what's going on in the wider world while still being contained enough to be a solitary story.
Maybe this a bit too harsh, bu

I really love these little Stormlight novellas between the enormous main entries, and I hope they continue.

Dawnshard gives us the most time we‚Äôve had so far with the previously interlude-only character Rysn, who I grew to like a lot throughout this book. I believe Brandon is on record as saying that she won‚Äôt occur as a main viewpoint character in the main books outside of interludes, which I think is a shame, but I hope she continues to be quite present as at least a non-viewpoint character. SUMMARY

Rsyn, The Lopen, Chiri-chiri, Cord, and others take a pirate-like boat trip to a mysterious island (view spoiler)

THE GOOD

Sanderson doesn't just show his power of words, but his growth as a writer and listener. Rsyn's suffering jumps off the page. see how none of the information is essentially for anyone who

I have a lot of thoughts on this book, I'll try to summarize them.

This is an adventure book, but not in the grander traditions folks are used to from the Stormlight Archives. This is a slower paced novella with less of a sense of impending doom. Reminds me a lot in style of The Voyage of the Dawn Treader or the child adventure novels of the early 1900s. Yes, there's adventure, but the adventure is more a frame for the theme.

I have a lot of thoughts on this book, I'll try to summarize them.

This is an adventure book, but not in the grander traditions folks are used to from the Stormlight Archives. This is a slower paced novella with less of a sense of impending doom. Reminds me a lot in style of The Voyage of the Dawn Treader or the child adventure novels of the early 1900s. Yes, there's adventure, but the adventure is more a frame for the theme.

And the theme is marvelous. It's all about understanding, expectations,

I am so impressed with this little short story. I think it contained so much in so few pages. It shows Mr. Sanderson's ability to write really well written stories no matter the length. I found myself particularly impressed with how he wrote the character Rysn. In previous entries, I have thought of her as a minor character and not one that I cared about all that deeply. I'll do my best to make this more than an ode to Brandon Sanderson. But first: I absolutely loved this book and will recommend it to everyone I know.

This is a short (by Sanderson's standards) 180 page novella, designed as a bridge between Stormlight 3 and 4.

This, the latest instalment in the stormlight archive does not disappoint. Dawnshard is a thoroughly enjoyable, humorous and also touching story from the viewpoint of Rysn and The Lopen.
From Rysn's view point the reader experiences an emotional and deep thought provoking exploration of what people who are paraplegic may experience . It is evident from the level of unique details that Brandon Sanderson has woven into the story he has researched this extensively and gives the reader a lot of food

Rysn has long been one of the most interesting interlude characters in the main sequence, and I've always wished that she was one of the main 10 characters who get a book to themselves. In the absence of that, this is quite a good substitute.

Sanderson's Novellas are about character development. He usually takes a side character (or two in this case) and fleshes them out. Dawnshard is the in between novella for Stormlight 3 and 4, much like Edgedancer was for Stormlight 2 and 3, and covers a sequence which could not fit in the main book but needed to be told nonetheless. I love this structurally because Stormlight books have always treaded the line between being stuffed with content and being bloated, and I hope that Brandon uses this format more frequently to take some pressure off the main installments.

A Phenomenal Look Into Phenomenal Characters

I don't know how he does it, but Brandon Sanderson has AGAIN managed to create full fledged character arcs seemingly in the span of a breath.

I have, sure, five, even ten, cousins who read it, and all said they were super impressed. ‚ÄúOh, Brightlord the Lopen, former king of Alethkar, I want to know more about your glowing!‚Äù I hear you ask. Well, I promise on the word of a newly two-armed Herdazian, there could be no better book to, sure, display my astonishing and heroic acts. Women, you will be overwhelmed by the amount of my greatness you will soon read of. I think there are a few

Well, what can I say?

It's a Brandon Sanderson book. It's Cosmere. It's Stormlight. That's basically all the information you'd need to know it's amazing.

It also has the (one and only) Lopen. He just adds the certain touch of Herdazian humor and his unique way of looking at things. (Can we also take a moment to appreciate the art for his chapters? It's just so perfect!)

Rysn also is a great character and I love that she got her own novella. She deserves it so much.

Also, Chiri-Chiri is adorable! And

really enjoyed both Rysn's and the Lopen's POVs!

and I can say probably nothing else that made me talk at the book because spoilers. but decent stuff considering it's meant to tide us over till Rhythm of War. a nice snack before the buffet.

Spoiler tag b/c i'm scared even though there are basically no details ahead: (view spoiler)

4.25/5
While I find novellas between books of a series unnecessary and boring, this proved to be the exact opposite. I think that if you're intending to read Rhythm of War, you should read this first, for the implications and revelations it has.
The characters focused here were brilliant for the short span of time they were present. Rysn was good to read, but I think she has SOOOO much more after the events of this book. Lopen has grown on me a lot, and I wish to see the crew of this ship again.

This was so much fun, and definitely jumped to being my favorite of Brandon‚Äôs shorter Cosmere works.

This book had it all: Both Rysn and Lopen were given amazing stories that really fleshed out their characters, this continued to flesh out the world-building of Roshar by giving us a first look at the mythical Amia, great action scenes, lots of introspection, great character insight, MASSIVE Cosmere-wide implications that I wasn‚Äôt expecting to get.

Brandon also just continues to improve as a writ

A relatively short one by Sanderson's standards, but I totally enjoyed it. I read it during a road trip this weekend and it made the whole thing go by so much faster than it would have otherwise.

You need to have read the rest of the Stormlight Archive in order to fully appreciate what's going on, but it's also written in a way that seems to let it stand independently as its own story (in the same way that Edgedancer was. ) Comparing the two - this one felt less climactic, yet deeper in weight an

I enjoyed this much more than I expected to considering I wasn't excited by the protagonist and I was previously let down by the other Stormlight novella, Edgedancer. Dawnshard doesn't have the crazy 3rd act that a lot of Sanderson works do. But he still manages to build a lot of tension while giving out very important information about the world and the series. I couldn't stop reading until I finished it from about the 60 percent mark. It's difficult to drop that much important cosmere lore whi

10/10

Sanderson made it once again!
This "novella" is a great improvement compared to Edgedancer, dont get me wrong, Edgedancer isnt bad but this one is just on a whole other level.
Such a great development to The Lopen, Cord, Huio and the cherry at the top of the cake, Rysn.
Rysn jumped some spots on my favorites list after this book, her story is heartbreaking and Sanderson once gain explores ilness¬¥s like no other author i have ever read.
Fans of SA and the Cosmere wont be dissapointed. This is a

An "unputdownable" novella that expands the bounds of the Cosmere

Brandon Sanderson's novels bring us these amazing stories in this marvelous universe that is the Cosmere... But I've found that it is in his shorter works that he explains the most of how it all works. Dawnshard contain many important details about the grander story behind the main novels, and that alone makes it worth a read... Add the Lopen to the mix and some of the more interesting mysteries so far shown in the Stormlight Archi

BIG COSMERE ENERGY. 4.5 stars.

Didn't know exactly what to expect going in, but as soon as it's established where we were going, I knew it was gonna be good. I wasn't all that excited about Lopen's sections for the most part, but I did like his resolution at the end. I really loved how Rysn's plot centers around her strengths specifically that have been built up for three books.

Another thing I really noticed in this book was how distinct all the characters felt. Maybe it's just because I have a m

A fun novella to get me back in the mood for the soon to be released, Rhythm of War. A tad towards a juvenile writing style. Not much depth.

Don't know if it adds anything to the current "Stormlight" characters. Guess I'll find out.

4 stars, only because the standards set by Sanderson are in the fucking stratosphere.

A very simple read, with some very important developments to the larger story of Stormlight Archive. But going through the book, it was obvious that Sanderson lacked proper time to flesh out the plot. It felt, at times, that some plot points were, very conveniently, converging together. But nevertheless, it is still a very solid read, and a great buildup for Rhythm of War. It is still rather funny that in just a

This was a very fun tidbit to read before the next official book of the series. Learning more about the Sleepless alone was interesting. I have no idea what I think about the Dawnshard yet. (view spoiler)

Lopen was, as always, super fun. I doubt I'd remain as enthralled with him if he was an actual major character of the books, but in small doses he's amazing. His oath was quite cool too. Kind of like Tefts but i

First know that if you haven't read at least the three main Stormlight Archives to date, this is NOT the place to start! Though if you, like me, haven't read the series in a little while, this IS a perfectly accessible point to jump back into it in preparation for Rhythms of War.

Dawnshard is truly delightful novella with a compelling story, amazing characters, and wonderful humor. The Lopen is funnier than ever, and it's great to get in-depth with Rysn, who I admit I only vaguely remember from t

I'll keep this short.

The Lopen. He truly shines here. He was amazing and funny before. Now he got some depth and is even more amazing. He's simply The Lopen.

There is a nice representation of people physical disabilities, we don't get to see that very often. It seems to me it was well done. I don't personally know anyone with physical disabilities, so I can't say for sure, but I can say that it made me think about the problems and doubts they face.

I'm glad Dawnshard was released before Rhythm o

What a punch this novella packs! I do not yet even understand all the implications this book reveals about the Cosmere, but I can‚Äôt wait for Rhythm of War next week and to hopefully see the characters developed here much more prominent in the main series!
The Lopen is my spirit animal (Radiant) and Rysn, Huio and Cord were an absolute delight to be introduced to further! Oh boy, can Sanderson give depth to characters when given the space.

Highly recommended and probably even compulsory to any St

Reading this sent me back to adventure stories I used to really enjoy. Stories where the characters set off into the unknown and must face danger every step of the way. King Solomon‚Äôs Mines, The Lost World, Treasure Island, Congo (book version) - this book is of the same spirit.

If I have a complaint it is that I want more. The story is great and the main characters (Rysn and Lopen) were both fun an interesting. It was especially great to learn more about The Lopen and see a bit of what is beneat

Thoroughly enjoyed this novella. It‚Äôs making me super excited to read Rysn‚Äôs interlude in Rhythm of War to see what happens with her. Def worth the read if ur looking for more Stormlight content! Plus we get more Lopen and he‚Äôs a blast to read.

This book has made Rysn shoot up in the ranks in terms of most liked stormlight characters for me. I really liked her POV chapters in this!

ALSO, Brandon seems to really understand the emotions of Rysn from losing her legs. He has obviously put a great deal

What a way to get me pumped up for Stormlight 4, Rhythm of War. Brandon Sanderson continues to be my comfort reading. Always very fun and enticing. This joins Edgedancer as novellas in between the major stormlight releases. Still mind blowing that he writes as fast as he does. Compared w/ Edgedancer, I would say that this one is a bit better. I think Rysn works really well as main protagonist, and then Lopen is always fun too. Overall I really enjoyed reading it, though in classic sanderson fash

I knew the story was about Rysn, so I was excited when realized that the Lopen is one of the side characters. Can't get enough of the guy.
The problem with this "short story" is that it gets over too soon. Luckily in it we got some interesting details about the world.
Overall it was a nice appetizer for Rhythm of War, which is coming out next year.

Great short story that fits perfectly inbetween Oathbringer and Rhythm of War (and really helps with the wait for the latter). Profits from the world-building in the rest of Stormlight (and other Cosmere books) to dive straight into the story, in which regard it definitely delivers. Having to spend no time introducing the characters, the book shines in the self-contained yet surprisingly connected story. An adventure with a clear goal, interesting three-dimensional characters and an action-packe

Not Sandersons best story, but still a highly enjoyable one especially in the early parts.
The climax wasn't as engaging as usual in a Sanderson book, yet I liked what happened.

As always with a Sanderson novel there are some really intriguing ideas and some really spicy implications for the cosmere (can't wait to read some theories).

It's been fun to have an appetizer for rhythm of War and the book did exactly what I wanted it to - distract me from the long wait that now begins again.

*small spoile

I read this novella right after finishing Oathbringer and am in eager anticipation of starting to read Rhythm of War when it is released in a few days. Overall it was very satisfying. One thing I always enjoy about reading Sanderson books is way he can illustrate in very relatable ways important aspects of the human condition, even though his stories are extremely fantastical. This story was no exception.

I marked it down a star because I felt that the resolution of the main conflict felt a bit

In a few days, book four of the Stormlight Archive will be released. To whet our appetite, we got this delightful novella. It‚Äôs a great story of a few side characters: the always funny Lopen and the intriguing trader Rysn (speaking of which, what‚Äôs with all the names with mostly consonants: Ksteld, Drwlan, etc.?). This story builds the world and offers questions we will wait years to answer (or maybe they‚Äôll be answered in Rythm of War?!?!).

Omg seriously 5 stars all around. This little novella is EVERYTHING. I love how Brandon Sanderson gave a voice to a disabled character in this weird world of his. AND we get to read a lot from Lopen's perspective, which was amazing. He makes what people assume is a one dimensional comedic relief character into something much, much more. I also love that Rysn had someone to relate to her, through her conversations with Lopen. Though his arm is now regrown since becoming a radiant, he gives a ton

Jumping back into Roshar right before the release of Rhythm of War was so nice. I haven't read a Sanderson book in about a year and I definitely missed his writing. I was very excited that we got to follow the Lopen when I first heard of this book but Rysn quickly grew on me as a character. I am in sales and it was very cool to see the "Sales Process" show up in one of my favorite series. I never would have thought following a merchant would be exciting. This is a book I wouldn't leave out if so

All in all a good read but some things seemed to be very convenient and I think the delivery fell a bit flat for the build up it had gotten. Mostly for the setting I was expecting something more grandiose.
I did like the characters, Rysn and of course The Lopen. They each had their arc fulfilled which were good. I guess 'a character' will be put on hiatus for a few books now and then pop up suddenly.
I expect a very small impact for Rhythm of War or even the first Stormlight Archive Arc.
Still lo

Rysn is one of my favorite characters in this series. I really wish we would get a little more of her and less of Shallan in the main series, but judging from the events of this book I‚Äôm confident that we will. It looks like there‚Äôs a lot of tie ins with the major cosmere universe that I‚Äôll have to research. There‚Äôs a fun story here and some good characters. It‚Äôs nowhere near as epic as the main books in the series, but it‚Äôs not trying to be and I think it pulls off what it was going for without

Dawnshard is what you expect/want a novella set in-between two epic (!) Stormlight Archive novels to be: easy, enjoyable, entertaining. So if you‚Äôre a fan of the series, you should definitely spend a leisurely afternoon getting to know Rysn, Lopen, Huio and Rock‚Äôs daughter Cord better. (In all fairness, Lopen is nowhere near my my favorite bridgemen but you can expect some character growth from him towards the end.)

I'm curious to find out to what extent this novella is relevant to Rhythm of War

Whereas Edgedancer felt like a true novella, like it stood by itself, Dawnshard feels like a few chapters taken from the next giant Stormlight book. Its tendrils extend deep into the events and characters of other books, and you've got to dig back into the deep lore of Stormlight to "get" this book.

It's a fun seafaring adventure, but I still don't really know what a Dawnshard is?!

Wow. For what is essentially a side piece to the main Stormlight series, I was shocked at how pertinent this story was. Not just to the Stormlight Archive, but the Cosmere and its fate as a whole.

Novellas like these just show that one should pay very close attention to the Interludes in the main books, as they are littered with Easter eggs and clues for future projects. It's made we want to go back and read Edgedancer, as I don't think I appreciated the gravity of that at the time.

Alas, that w

4.5 stars. It's a little slow in the first half, and I'm not sure that the second half would make up for it on its own. However, for the Cosmere aware reader, the secrets revealed are amazing and astounding. No spoilers, but let's just say that the dawnshards are not what I thought they were.

I loved Rysn's heroics at the climax, and we see more depth and growth of character from the Lopen than anything we've seen from the other Stormlight books. This is a solid and important addition the Stormli

Absolutely amazing. Much like Edgedancer, it was great to see some of the stranger parts of Roshar get fleshed out, and Rysn has grown so much as a character. Giving her her own novella was a perfect capstone to her arc and I can't wait to see what comes next.

High seas and exploration books are always fun in general and this one really knocks it out of the park. Strong Voyage of the Dawn Treader vibes going on, in the best way.

A fun read that focuses on the interesting side characters of Rysn and The Lopen. I appreciate Brandon's diligence to get the details of Rysn's handicap accurate. The Lopen's journey of self-discovery through his conversations with Huio were meaningful but of course still had humor, and I love seeing different character's unique Ideals. This is a Stormlight novella (a long novella) that was made available last week as part of the recent Kickstarter that Brandon did for the leather bound edition of The Way of Kings. It's self-contained, but you really benefit from knowing the backstory of several of the characters. It was also a very enjoyable way of bringing the whole Stormlight universe back into my fore-brain after three years, ready for Rhythm of War which is coming out in about ten days time.

Besides being one of the shortest books ever (thanks, Brandon Sanderson, for thinking a novel-length book is ‚Äúshort‚Äù), Dawnshard was a lot of fun.

Getting the perspectives of The Lopen and Rysn was entertaining to say the least, and there were some powerful messages in the story as well. Exciting action and some juicy cosmere tidbits to boot. Let‚Äôs just say that, as I anticipate the release of Rhythm of War, Dawnshard was far too short.

This is certainly a far shorter novel (technically a novella) than Brandon's normal fare and it certainly was a much smaller affair though still packed with a lot of juicy details. Frankly, I'm surprised there was as much relevant information for the Cosmere here. I loved reading Rysh, Lopen and Cord. I wish there was an infinite pages to follow side chracters go on their own journey and path. Now I can't wait for the 4th stormlight book. Here we go!

4.5 / 5

Well that certainly was A LOT of informations.

I just read it in one sitting (always nice to be able to do that with a Sanderson story). I really enjoyed the two POV of Rysn and Lopen. It was a lot of fun (especially with Lopen's chapters) and now I'll go read stuff on reddit and on the coppermind wiki because I'm sure I've missed a lot of informations..!

Oh also , Sanderson does horror now? I wasnt ready for this üòÇ

This is probably my new favourite of Sanderson's companion short stories - probably because it didn't feel so much like a random "side quest", but far more integral to the overall story. Several characters we have met before, and it was nice to get to know them better. The pacing was good (which is often a problem I have with his work), and the plot was good. Not a super exciting installment, but I did enjoy it.

Okay, so, *that* happened.

Wow.

I was expecting a fill-in-the-gaps-btween-novels piece, similar to Edgedancer.

I was not expecting....well....that.

Which is to say, Dawnshard is one of the most important installments in the Cosmere.

And I am very excited to see that one of my favorite characters, who thusfar has had a very minor role in the Stormlight series, may soon become one of the most important figures in Sanderson's mythos.

Rysn is one of my favorite side characters and I was so unbelievably happy to read her novella!! She's so great. I enjoyed the story as well and as per usual Brandon Sanderson fashion, I have a ton more questions!!!

My only complaint is Lopen. I really can't stand his character mostly. I don't understand why anyone thinks he's funny or a fun character, he's just so annoying. However, it seems at the end there may be some changes in his character so we'll hopefully see if he gets tolerable.

Truth be told, I don't expect to like Rhythm of War as much as I liked this tightly written, just plain fun, novella. Turns out when restricted to a shorter format and to exploring the corners, edges and side-characters of Roshar, I find myself entertained and compelled just as much, if not more than in the (much, much) longer novels. It helps that Rysn has always been a highlight of the main novels' interludes, and now finds herself undeniably among the best characters of the series.

Overall, I loved this book. Mostly on the lighter side, which is what I'm looking for these days. Lopen and Rysn were great as main POV characters, as were some of the side characters. The tidbits for overall Cosmere was unexpected.

If I had to nitpick, there were plenty of things happening that it would've needed a much longer book to give them justice, especially the decisions made in the climax.

It is a novella. Never expect too much from a Novella, but it was still a good one.

I really missed this world, and even if The Lopen was the only character that featured in the main parts of the previous books, he was still awesome as always.

And Sanderson putting so much character development into Rysn in some 100 pages shows how great of a storyteller he is.

Also the ending leaves us with more questions than answers as always. Can‚Äôt wait for RoW release next week. HYPE!

I loved this book. Heartfelt, positive story. I‚Äôm a sucker for stories that explore new places, creating something new, and making even small, side characters awesome. Rysn shines all over in the book. The amount of work Brandon has done for Rhysn is to be appreciated.

This book has significant Cosmere mysteries. I really liked how he gives just enough information to make fans hungry for more.

I have already finished part 1 of ROW. Need to wait only 2 more days. Yippee.

Definitely enjoyed this addition! I was so glad to see some characters appear and glad to delve into a side character more. I love the perspective of the main character, a unique one you don't see often in literature. This novella also makes the mysteries of Roshar and the Cosmere all the more intriguing.

I did feel that some of the plot was too convenient and a solution to a previous problem too easily solved, pushing believability, thus the four stars.

Fantastic, an easy 5! Some of my favorite side-characters teaming up to go to my favorite side-location to reveal some majorly central new lore. This is basically the perfect book for me. Hard to explain exactly what I mean without going into specifics but this short novel not only majorly advances characters I DO like, it was a huge step forward for one character I have so far really been disliking.

Without spoiling anything this is absolutely required reading for Stormlight and Cosmere fans.

I LOVED THIS SO FREAKING MUCH!!!!

This was seriously SO much better than I was expecting???? I mean, I shouldn‚Äôt doubt a Sanderson book... but novellas are normally boring guys- filler books. THIS THOUGH!? That was the most fun and depressingly gross book I‚Äôve read in Fantasy!!

(I think I need more books written on ships)

I‚Äôm gonna read Edgedancer next (I skipped it cause I don‚Äôt like novellas- don‚Äôt come at me) because I loved this so much, I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll love it too!!

Truly, truly exception. Every sentence is filled with purpose, and every event is rich with lore. With that said, we have soundly left the Sanderson era where you can pick up and read more or less anywhere. I've heard this book advertised as a possible standalone and it most certainly is not. I would say this novella requires not just knowledge of the previous Stormlight books, but as many others as you can get read.

I read this book in two sittings and the only reason it took two is that I started reading it too late in the evening and literally could not stay awake long enough to finish it.

It's a lovely novella that adds interesting pieces to the Cosmere-puzzle (at least for me who haven't read so many Cosmere books yet), and lets you get closer to characters you haven't gotten the chance to spend so much time with.

Oh my GOD was this good! Not that I'm surprised--Elise Kova can't write a bad book. This has a Hades and Persephone feel to it, but it's not a retelling--and the world Elise has created! I seriously hope there are more books to explore the rest of it! SO GOOD!!

Stealing this review space to add a note or two about the book...

This book was a passion project for me. It was my first book back writing again after being near burn-out. And I started drafting it at the beginning of quarantine in 2020. I wanted to write a world that I could escape into... where everything was wrapped up with a happily ever after at the end. It's my earnest hope that others can find an escape in the pages of Eldas and Luella.
