The hunt to figure out why the previous Human Queens have not succeeded in solving the slow drain of midscape is quite interesting.

Eldas and Luella relationship has a rough start as she has no clue that sh

Elise has done it again!!!

This was a delightful tale of a young lady trapped in a cycle that must be broken. I loved the courage of this protagonist. She is courageous and loyal and not willing for anyone to tell her no. She tackles a seemingly impossible problem with trepidation, yet clarity that if she doesn't solve the problem, two worlds would die slow and painful deaths.

Kova is again brilliant, building tensions over the impending situation while also bringing us along with a growing love b

I very much rate books based off enjoyment and oh boy did I enjoy this one. It was hard to put down with such an engaging plot that constantly had something happening. I very much enjoyed the authors descriptions, sometimes I find books can waste time on details, but the author managed to paint an intricate world easily.

I was honestly obsessed with the main love interest, spectacularly written. I found the ending to be quite satisfying, wrapping it all up in a neat bow. I personally found the s

Thank you for sending me this ARC. This book hooked me from the first chapter and those are the books that I know are going to be good. I loved the book and the fantasy world that Elise created. I was actually pleasantly surprised that this was a stand-alone book as all books these days seem to be a series. I loved that it was a stand-alone and I got old-fashioned fairy-tale vibes from this book. All in all it was a great read and it comes highly recommended.

Elise Kova has woven yet another spectacular world of magic, romance, and page-turning narrative.

I had the privilege of reading an early copy of this magnificently written book and it was impossible to put down!!!!

I CAN'T EVEN PUT INTO WORDS HOW I FEEL ABOUT THIS BOOK BUT LET ME SIMPLIFY IT FOR YOU: READ IT ASAP.

I. NEED. MORE.

A DEAL WITH THE ELF KING is the beautifully written story of Luella, a 19-year-old woman who has dedicated her life to helping others through herbology. She lives on one side of the Fade, the Natural World that exists in tandem with Midscape, the land where magical creatures live. Midscape is overseen by the Elf King, and he comes every so often to the Natural World to claim a Human Queen, a girl born every generation with magical powers. A delightful love story!

No spoilers, but if you‚Äôve read as much Koontz as I have, you have an idea how it ends. I just wanted to make sure I was right, and it was better than I imagined.

I think I‚Äôm gonna have to reread some of his older books now because this makes me all nostalgic.

Very intriguing topic: parallel universes

Well written and very thought out. Parallel universes have always interested me and this book was everything you could want when exploring that world or worlds. Would recommend to anyone to read it, I may read it twice. I‚Äôve always wanted there to be parallel universes, where people still live and laugh, long after they have died. Wonderful book. Thank you Dean Koontz, you‚Äôve done it again!

I had given up on Dean Koontz several years ago. I was tired of similar storylines with just enough good character development and action to keep me interested. His writing is still excellent as far as it goes. When I read the blurb for Elsewhere, I was intrigued. And I enjoyed it while it lasted, but then suddenly, it just ended. I don't think I'll waste my time again, but rather give my money and attention to newer writers with better ideas and execution.

I want to preface this by saying he is one of my favorite authors. This is exactly why this book was so disappointing. The whole thing from start to finish felt very rushed, not a lot of character depth, no massive emotional connections. I truly felt like the book started off okay but then quickly wrapped everything up as if he ran out of time for a deadline. I highly recommend him as an author but I would skip this one.

I received ARC from Goodreads. Thank you so much. It has been a while since I read a Dean Koontz book and this did not disappoint.. A page turner and in parts so scary I had to put it down .The story of single dad Jeffy Coltrane and his precocious 11-year-old daughter Amity, and the parallel worlds it explores. There is genocidal robots marching and a predictable sociopathic bad guy who will do anything to lay his hands on the special device.

Top of his game

As an avid fan of Koontz‚Äôs books, he‚Äôs quite the literary master. This book was so much fun, I have to wonder what it‚Äôs like to know him personally. So many different and complex stories! I always felt a connection to him because we had goldens too. Our Trixie was near the same age as his, our Wilson when he had Anna. I can‚Äôt name a favorite, because they‚Äôre all great, but this one is way up there, along with Jane Hawk. Keep writing, Dean!

Time for hope

Dean Koontz is an amazing writer. Who always manages to scare the crap out of me with his stories. He also then leaves me with hope for the good in the world. Especially at this point in history I needed a sign of hope. This book gave it to me. Thank you for clearly seeing what‚Äôs happening in our world Mr Koontz but then reminding us to fight the good fight till the real end.

The best Dean Koontz book in years. I have been reading Dean Koontz for over 35 years. This is a reminisce of some of his early work dealing with scientific inventions. If you are familiar with his books like Lightning, Strangers, Midnight, etc., you will enjoy this. This is a psychological thriller with science fiction. Koontz shows his imagination off in this novel. The conclusion could end in many different ways, and that leaves you wanting more.

A Smarmy Thriller.

I have very mixed feelings about Dean Koontz. Sometimes, Odd Thomas, I find his work both compelling and finely wrought. Other times, the Frankenstein series, it leaves me completely unmoved. Elsewhere is both overcooked and underdone, with annoying know-it-all characters that are too damned spunky for their own good. So, there is such a thing as a smarmy would-be thriller after all, and this is it.

I pre-ordered my copy from Amazon.ca, and opened it early this morning. Needless to say, I did absolutely nothing all day except read. I couldn‚Äôt out it down. Koontz hasn‚Äôt lost his touch. It has lots of action, suspense, likeable characters, vile vile villain, heartwarming ending (I wish other writers would tie up all loose ends like Mr. Koontz.) and a mouse and one dog. I loved it!

Great Story

Well done, as usual; with excellent scene setting and character developments. Typical Koontz‚Äôs novel with bad government and good citizens. Loved the action. The only ever negative in Koontz‚Äôs novels are the over the top on psychological character discussion and realizations; which always makes my eyes glaze over and causes me to speed read through it. :-)

I received this book as a Goodreads Giveaway. Advanced Readers Copy.
I like Dean Koons. But...I sometimes found Amity‚Äôs voice annoying or her actions. I know he was making her brave, but it sometimes seemed there was too much internal discourse about it.
That aside, I think he made the premise believable and interesting. Easily read.

Point of view

This story was written from a twelve year old girls point of view. I prefer a dogs view Point and Dean does a great job writing both. Having been a twelve year old girl I was surprised by how different Amity is from me (at that age).
This sixty year old lady enjoyed the story. In the end, all any of us can (and should) be is the best version of ourselves.

A father/daughter tale of parallel dimensions, loss and pain, dangerous men, crazy ass chimpoids, a sweet white mouse, fresh starts and happy endings. My only complaint is that it was too rushed. It felt like watching a movie with the fast forward button. I could have had more background with all of the characters. This would make a great series.

Awesome as always...

All of Koontz‚Äôs books should be titled Intensity! I find myself having to take breaks to relieve tension, but also to prolong the story.
This book is everything we‚Äôve come to love and expect from Koontz. Tense, harrowing, highly emotional. The good guys are ace, the bad guys the worst possible evil this world can grow.
Read it! You won‚Äôt be sorry.

Unless my memory betrays me, I think this is the first time that Koontz has dabbled in the world of parallel universes and I must say... bravo! My only complaint is that it wasn't long enough. I could have read another 500 pages involving these lovable characters. I'm completely incapable of being unbiased when it comes to Koontz, however, so read for yourself and decide!

Knocks it out of the park again

Dean Koontz once again creates protagonists we love and bad guys that deserve to be hated. He‚Äôs a master story teller and creates a multi-verse that is both frightening and includes a hidden gem. I highly recommend this book for all Koontz, sci-fi, and urban fantasy fans.

There is plenty of suspense in this story. I was yelling at Jeffy not to open the box holding the key to everything. The multiverse has some frightening parallel Earths. Jeffy is a great dad and has done a good job raising Amity on his own. Amity is a wonderful young lady and will grow up to be an exceptional woman, IMO.
As usual, there is a happy ending.

4.5 stars because it held my interest and Koontz really upped the tension and peril as the book went on. He had a bit too many flowery descriptions of scenery and weather, though. I loved the concept of the story. 11 yr old Amity is very precocious, and the bad guy is only-in-a-novel over the top bad, but the story has a decent climax and conclusion with all loose ends tied up.

I received a copy of Elsewhere for review purposes.

For some reason I never read any of Mr Koontz books before (!) and I am so happy to finally have gotten my hands on one of them.

I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs more adventure than horror, but it is certainly a fun read and a good introduction to Dean Koontz‚Äô work. Thank you for this gift.

It is already on my share list.

Sci fi that is fast paced and full of action. Interesting to see how Mr. Koontz explains the theory of parallel universe for all to understand while still maintaining the reader‚Äôs interest. Highly recommend for the battle between good and evil.
Thank you to Goodreads and the Publisher for an ARC of this book.

I was disappointed in this story. It had so much potential to be filled with action and adventure but it fell far short. Instead it was filled with a large amount of what I call "describing the scene", describing what the scenery looked like and what was going on in the mind of the characters. I found this to be quite boring. Luckily it was filled with enough action that I completed the book.

I liked the interplay between the father and daughter characters and the first half of the book was really good. Problem for me became the lack of visits to the multiverse. The discovery and creativeness of those worlds in the beginning was cool. The end of the book became predictable and the additional characters just blah.

I loved this book. The premise behind the story was pretty interesting (though there were a few issues with it). But I feel like it could have been more. Everything went by so fast. The potential was there to make this something huge. It could have gone in many directions and a lot could have been explored, but it never got there. A nearly prefect Koontz book.

I enjoyed this book. It was fast-paced and had likeable characters, the concept was interesting ... It just felt formulaic to me, almost shallow in that it didn't delve very deeply into the things that actually made it interesting. A good, quick read for those who like their stories straightforward and tidy.

Excellent of course!

Dean Koontz is an author who can write anything and make it believable. I know we are part of a mult-verse. I've taken courses on cosmology by Dr. Michel Kauku (sp.). It's amazing how a fiction writer can take a theory, intertwine a group of characters, add adventures and evil to produce a compelling, fun read. Bravo!

Overall a good story. I enjoyed the characters and the bad guy wasn't too over the top crazy. I get tired of Dean Koontz having super smart children in his books and was glad he didn't do that in this book (she was smart, but not like a genius that acts too adult for their age) .

I was also pretty satisfied with how it ended.

Mr. Koontz has written a great book. Read it, just foe fun

This book has all the elements necessary for a great example of fun reading.

The pages of Elsewhere enthralled me from pretty much in the first few pages.

I would recommend it for anyone who is looking an amazing and immensely satisfying reading experience.

Yet again, we see the genius of Mr. Dean Koontz's writings!
What a wonderful, horrible book! I wasn't sure, until the end if it would be a stand alone or the beginning of a series.
Jeffy and Amity are great characters, as well as Falkirk.
This is so good! I love the worlds!
Enjoy!
BTW I won this ebook copy on Goodreads!

Koontz can turn a phrase Luke no like no other. This particular book provided a glimpse into the author's views about current day politics and the activist climate. His knowledge of ballistics is spot-on this was a very uplifting novel utilizing some of the current views by physicists about the nature of the universe. The characters were well drawn and sympathetic. The villain was Pure Evil.

DK is back! I‚Äôm normally pretty stingy with the 5 stars, and maybe this is actually 4.75 but it was a wild ride. I was even almost a little disappointed there wasn‚Äôt more golden retriever action üòÇ. This is a book I would stay up late reading because the action is nonstop, it‚Äôs spooky, and some how funny even during the horror. Definitely recommend for the sci-fi and old school Koontz fans

A True Koontz Delivery

As always when I pick up a Koontz book, I expect an easy read that will take me away from more serious matters of life. This one did not fail. The innocent father, the brave little girl and a somewhat crazy scientist traveling through worlds. What could be better. Loved it til the end.

In ‚ÄúElsewhere‚Äú, Dean Koontz‚Äôs writes a thriller that goes to parallel worlds. This is not as good as other Koontz‚Äôs books. The main characters are likable but the government agents running amok is a overboard. Not sure if Koontz was trying to just turn out another book, but this book was not one of his best.

I did finish

I almost did not finish this. I was reading on my kindle and at 35% read I felt my vocabulary was improved. But, I had no idea what the main story was even about. Then a realization came to me. Most of Koontz books are all about the ending. So I trudged through stuff that was filler. The ending was a little fairytale. He has others that were so much better.

This must have been good - read it in a day and don't usually do that. The characters were likable (or hateable) as needed. I find the whole idea of a "multiverse" somewhat silly and can't imagine a purpose for it, other than to tell a pretty good story. A few bad words are uttered by - or about - the hateables, but I would still recommend this book.

Sometimes you just need an honest to goodness happy ending. Koontz returns to his old self with a fun yet appropriately contemplative ride through the multiverse. This story smacks both of Odd Thomas, alongside a wondering optimism (a hope residing in the arms of mercy) that the world really needs right now.

Another winner

It seems decades ago I read my first Dean Koontz novel. I loved the mystery, intrigue and actual physicality of locations. As a fine wine, time has only improved his prose and the ability to keep the reader engaged from page one to the very end. I loved this book but will not give away any of it‚Äôs secrets-an excellent read and highly recommended.

3.5 stars, but I rounded it up to 4. I feel like I should have enjoyed it more, but maybe I just wasn't in the mood? Reminded me of Dark Matter with traveling through parallel universes. One thing that bothered me was how abrupt the ending seemed, all tied up neatly and quickly. I could have used a little more!

This is an exciting, fast paced read with tension filled moments. I loved the world jumping and the different earths they encountered. I didn't enjoy being in the bad guy's head. I also thought it was a bit silly here and there. The ending was nice. I always love Koontz' books and it's a fun read but not quite as good as DEVOTED was in my opinion.

Is it sci-fi, horror, suspense or all of that? I‚Äôve always entertained the notion of parallel universes and Elsewhere puts forth many what-ifs. I enjoyed how Koontz intertwined Amity‚Äôs reading with her use of her common sense. Books are meant for escape, but also, as I this one, plausible solutions to life‚Äôs issues.

Mr. Koontz manages to make a large-arc story about interdimensional travel thrilling, understandable and very personal, because his protagonists grab you and hold you to their plight and don't let go. The bad guy is very very bad but totally believable. I love the way Mr. Koontz slides the narrative point-of-view between characters seamlessly. A dang good read!

The beginning was a little murky for me, but pretty soon i couldn't stop reading, you know to work, make dinner ;)

This was slightly unusual for Koontz, different worlds, normally he sets different things within our own. He did a nice job of it. i like both the idea of moving sideways, not forwards or back, as well as Michelle's musings on all of your alternatives forming a whole...hmmm

FICTION, FICTION

At the very beginning, you must feel the connection between their worlds to which they were ported and our current world of 2020. They did not have the Pandemic, but to me, the politics seemed so much the same as ours.. ..There was much that was scary in this book, just as there is today....

I am a HUGE Koontz fan. Forever. Lightning is one of my favorite books of all time. Elsewhere is not. I was disappointed having waited with baited breath for it to release. Great premise. Liked the characters. But, pretentious, endless droning on about every little detail of anything/any thought and done so frequently - turned me off.

Touched the Heart

As the headline says. He touched the heart again. He‚Äôs a master at mixing knuckle-biting moments with quiet ones of joy. I choose him for this reason. Also, because he loves animals and they are as important a character as any of the humans. I would recommend his work to anyone who enjoys a good read.

'Elsewhere' took me by surprise. Well written and well thought out. The story line pulled me in from the beginning and kept me glued to the pages. Full of great characters, incredibly creative scenarios and action. Jeffy and Amity made the best leads. Definitely a must add to your tbr list. Recommended read.

Jeffy Coltrane and his daughter Amity (11) have created a special bond since Jeffy's wife Michelle left them when Amity was just four years old. Jeffy and Amity wish that Michelle would walk back into their world. Jeffy befriends an old hobo named Ed who talks about the "key to everything". I don't like horror but I was unable to put this book down.

Jeffrey Coltrane and his daughter, Amity, come into possession of a device that enables travel between numerous parallel worlds. Amity is convinced it can be used to find her missing mother and all hell breaks loose. Reminiscent of his early novels, Koontz takes a scientific theory and spins it into an intriguing, entertaining SF story with plenty of action.

I am an avid reader of Dean Koontz, but this one is not his best effort. The premise is interesting - a man and his daughter are given a mysterious gizmo that seems to move them between different timelines and worlds. The close calls and ill-timed events that occur seem forced and fake to keep the action moving. Jumping around timelines causes confusion and frustration. Disappointing.

Suspenseful and heartwarming

I like happy endings & this story has one but, Koontz does his usual great job of not giving that away too soon. Not as preachy as some of his novels never the less gratitude for what one has comes thru loud & clear.

Dean does it again

I‚Äôve loved every book of his, and this one is no exception! A page-turner for sure, full of suspense and horror, thrills and victories. Thank you Dean for this gift!

Received this in the mail today and immediately sat down to read it! I loved the parallel universes and the main characters were people you wanted to root for. I would love to read more about some of the worlds they encountered!

Read This

I have read & followed Mr Koontz for at least 30 years now, and reading this story, I am reminded of why. His words used to describe something, while terrific prose, make it crystal clear in your mind what he‚Äôs saying. Awesome. I‚Äôm somewhat speechless.

I am not a very good review writer but as one other reviewer said there was a lack of major character development usually his books are a lot longer and may be that gives you more ownership into the characters. Was a good listen with a feel good ending.

Mind-bending, riveting read

This is one you have to read in one sitting, and maybe read again to be sure you didn‚Äôt miss anything! I sincerely hope we get to explore other Elsewheres in new books, although I genuinely enjoyed the ending of this one.

Not the usual Dean Koontz story, but thoroughly enjoyable, and an absolute Joy to go for the ride to Earth 1.0, etc.,etc.,etc. A Love story wrapped in an enigma, and slid sideways along the paths of Elsewhere....PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE, Write more stories about the "Key to Everything"

Masterpiece

This is the Dean Koontz that never lets me down. The imagination and writing style are so bizarre yet pull you deep into the story. I highly recommend this book. I honestly think that with each reading you will find hidden gems that you missed before.

Don DeLillo is still giving his readers something to think about in this short, yet powerful book. It‚Äôs ominous; even the cover is somewhat haunting - black background except for a slender cell phone and the print. It‚Äôs centered around what happens on a day in the future, on Super Bowl Sunday in 2022-pretty scary since this is a not too distant future date. An interesting book about a pandemic of a different type that infects not humans, but the power grid. I‚Äôm a fan of Don DeLillo and his ideas are always weird and pensive and fascinating and this is no different.

First the book begins with a couple in a plane, before and after a crash landing into the new world without power or screens. DeLillo as always captures a new strange atmosphere and impending doom very adeptly and creepily.

The book also, very eerily, captures the feeling of being in a pan

Had a couple of hours to myself tonight. Decided to sit down with my old friend Don. Poured a glass of bourbon to accompany. A good drink really does go hand in hand with his writing.

Anyway, the book. The book is good. Delillo has a lot to say in very few words. Nobody writes like him and his familiar prose is here to please yet again. The surreal atmosphere is back too. The handful of characters are all walking the balance beam between despair and acceptance. Process first, react later.

The Fifth Most Overrated Thing in Life

Christopher Hitchens once wrote, "The four most overrated things in life are champagne, lobster, anal sex, and picnics."

To those, I will add Don DeLillo novellas.

This novella was unintentionally comical and absolutely weird: the equivalent of bathroom stall musings and scatological stream of consciousness by gnomic horndogs along with their black-turtlenecked conversations with pretentious New England teases.

This is a new DeLillo long short story in the guise of a novel. It had a few crystalline moments, but added up to a less satisfying whole than any of his other works. Make sure you read Underworld, White Noise and the seldom mentioned Angel Esmeralda before you try this one. DeLillo is still one of America's best living writers, but like the new Lethem book, this is a minor work, and also capitalizes on current societal anxieties. I have never read anything by DeLillo, but now I'm intrigued.
I have learned in other reviews that this one is not up to his usual standard, so I'm curious to see how his good works read.

The atmosphere of complete passivity displayed in this novella managed to mesmerize me. We don't learn anything that happened we only see the reactions - or better non-reactions - of 5 characters trying to watch a match on TV when power goes off. It is layed bare how little those people are able to connect with e

Impressionistic and detached, with some nice sentences and scenes, but an unclear purpose and ending to it

The book (I feel novel is a to generous term, the lettertype is quite big and it is only slightly above 100 pages) follows 5 people on the brink of the Superbowl 2022. One day in 2022,

Is there anything better than the interstellar bursts of Don DeLillo's sentences? Not much, so we salivate over those we are given. Even the crumbs and scraps. This book (novella) might be the crumbs and scraps we need to sate our hunger. But it's not a full-course meal.

I can't be the only one longing for another big brick from DeLillo like Underworld, or something compact and dense like White Noise, Mao II, or Libra. It's unfair to have set such a high standard with past works that decent, fun,

Read the advance review copy in a single sitting, and it's marvelous, DeLillo's peculiarly lyrically lean and meaningful prose ever present. And then there is the form, which I'd place somewhere in between the starkness, concision, ellipses of his shorter novels and the entropy, silence, and absurdity of his plays. Also, I'd say it's a book-length engagement with two propositions by Wittgenstein, namely, "Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent" and "The world is everything that is

We're all intertwined and embedded in technology, screens and digital mediums and yet we fear them. We are aware of how much power they hold over us, how dependent we are on them ‚Äì so what if all the screens went black?



The idea of the novella is a simple one: In 2022, five people want to come together for a dinner in an apartment in Manhattan. We watch them converse and engage ‚Äì it's the night of the Super Bowl after all. But then a disruption follows: all screens go black.

Why is it scary to t

Some critics claim DeLillo is out of touch, but this compressed and hyper-stylized story feels straight-up oracular, cutting too close to the bone to offer any comfort. It's an elegy for the loss of culture as we watch the characters shrug off the last vestiges of historical memory.

If there's one thing DeLillo always nails, it's our modern insecurities and anxieties, but the last few most recently published DeLillo novels all read like someone else trying to craft something DeLilloesque. This one is no exception.

I will still read everything he publishes, if only for his solipsistic character dialogue. Something about it is calming to me. It's like his characters exist in their own worlds, independent to one another. When they converse, they speak to imagined others in thei

Although I have read all of Don DeLillo's books, those that I read prior to joining goodreads don't show up on my feed. He's one of those writers I've followed for over 30 years, no matter what prior reviewers think. His style is distinctive. His viewpoint specific. I'll repeat from a prior review since it applies here as well: "In the years since publishing Underworld, DeLillo has written novels of spare prose, sharp and focussed that leave the reader disquieted and thoughtful. There is not an

The Silence is a very engrossing read, if you're interested in starting it you might as well leave the world behind for an hour or so just fo finish this.

While I did find the amount of information, theorizing, and amazing writing Don DeLillo was able to cram into the short span of one hundred pages impressing, there was just one big issue for me. And my big issue was the changing focus. We spend the first half of the book talking about characters and setting up an almost horrific atmosphere, bu

DeLillo's newest offering is short and thought provoking and as usual, prescient. Imagined before Covid-19 hit (but not so far ahead that they couldn't insert a quick reference), The Silence describes a sudden event where all digital connections have been severed and humanity is forced to interact in its old ways. Present is DeLillo's stunning writing. Not a word wasted and sentences beautiful in their simplicity and striking in their multiple and layered meanings.

As I‚Äòve stumbled through the hazy collection of days and murky assembly of weeks that have made up pandemic, I‚Äôve thought many times about how much more difficult this would all be if it had happened when I was a child. How impossible it would have been if, in 1990, we had all been forced to sequester in our homes.

There would have been no internet through which to digitally connect.

No Netflix on which to binge.

No cellphones with which to text.

It would have been truly isolating.

Truly difficult.

When we‚Äôre talking about the best American writers of the past half-century, everyone‚Äôs going to have a different list, but there are certain names that will likely appear on most of them. One of those names is Don DeLillo, who has written some of the most impactful literature of his generation. Books like ‚ÄúWhite Noise,‚Äù ‚ÄúUnderworld‚Äù and others are significant parts of the 20th century canon.

And he‚Äôs still going strong.

DeLillo‚Äôs latest novel ‚Äì his 17th, bu

DeLillo crafts a static filled atmosphere in The Silence as power and communications go down on Super Bowl Sunday in 2022. Jim and Tessa are on plane from Paris to New York discussing mundane contextual details about the data and statistics they are consuming on an in-flight screen. Max and Diane are hosting a Super Bowl party of which the guests include Jim and Tessa along with a former student of Diane's named Martin. An event of some kind causes a shut down devices, phones, TVs, airplane syst

Our truth is a facade; every DeLillo novel seems not only to suggest but prove that such is the case. Our truth is a facade. In his latest work, the characters are confronted by the next global disaster in 2022 and they are don't seem to make such a big deal of it. The terrible inertia of 2020 supressed by a semblance of order comes to the surface and takes over. They react to thier disaster- like we did to the lockdown three months after it was imposed- with apathetic resignation. Even the most

DeLillo tales familiar banal events‚Äîlooking at the screen on the seat in front of you on an airplane, watching a football game on TV‚Äîand creates a Rothko-like poetry by distilling the events to a DNA-strand kind of abstraction.

When a student‚Äôs obsession with Einstein‚Äôs handwritten texts gets reformulated by another character as erotic storytelling, there comes to seem something (deliberately) Alzheimer-ish about DeLillo‚Äôs approach: shaving the familiar emotions from familiar experiences and redu

I'm more or less a fan of DeLillo, but either I didn't get this one or there isn't a lot to get, and I think it's mostly the latter. He covers the themes he does so well, primarily a particularly contemporary sort of anxiety. The novella should be chopped to short story length -- even at 100ish pages, it drags. The characters aren't characters, which is fine, but as simple mouthpieces for vague uneasiness, they don't work, particularly since none of them feel or say anything that especially cont

I knew when I read a recent interview with DeLillo where he came off as smug and coy that I might dislike this novel. And it is indeed overhyped and a chore to read.

Obnoxious, barely drawn characters (e.g. Tessa is "dark-skinned" and her husband Jim is "tall"), pretentious dialogue that strains belief, and mediocre prose. Interesting engagement with spectacle and mediatization, exploring a scenario that we've likely all thought of at one time or another: a total technological blackout. However, The Silence is impeded by its brevity. It feels sparser than any other DeLillo work - even more so than Point Omega - and just doesn't devote enough time to developing its core themes in a way that feels satisfying and memorable, which is ironic given the loss-of-memory incurred by the death of the digital world. A sliver of a novel, double spacing with a typewriterish/screenplayish font. Eerily prescient as it - of course - is about a catastrophic world event which sends everyone into a paroxysm of anxiety and paralysis. Obligatory mention of viruses, face masks, etc. Variations on themes DeLillo has been honing his whole life. People might feel a bit cheated by this liliputian offering but I see it as Neil Young does - 'it's all one song'. DeLillo's post-Underworld work operates as a series of annexes,

We were headed in this direction. No more wonder, no more curiosity. Totally impaired orientation. Too much of everything from too narrow a source code.

Just not long enough. A mere 116 pages--as long as some books of poetry, which is really what this is. It's page after page of words that sound good together, phrases that resonate; it's a savoring of words and syllables but also of contemporary angst. I also kept thinking it read like a play. In any case, it leaves you wanting more.

In late 2018, DeLillo said to The Guardian about writing, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what‚Äôs keeping me alive,‚Äù and so It‚Äôs our good fortune as readers that The Silence is the result. Like his recent novels, it‚Äôs spare and sharp‚Äîcompletely relevant to this moment in America and just shy of terrifying.

He's a cryptoluddite now - he made me feel bad for reading this on my computer - something about his luddite turn brought some of his better, sharper dialogue from his earlier work back out - skeletal characters & prose poems, a lot of blank space towards the back of the book, no more than what is needed - the quiet observation of Point Omega tightened - no winners among the characters - probably a good book to be his last, if he doesn't write another - can't pick between 3 and 4 stars and since

this is more a long short story than a novel, but put simply it's about how we talk past each other when we don't have technology running interference for us. delillo's characters don't talk to each other, they speak in corresponding monologues that repeat the thought patterns that exist concurrently to what we consume. when we subtract that consumption, the thought patterns don't have dance partners, least of all the thought patterns of other people in the room.

It's Super Bowl Sunday 2025. Three friends are in New York watching the game and one couple is flying in on an international flight when everything goes off the Grid. A short novel that is thought-provoking and captures our reliance on the outside. I am a fan of DeLillo.

Don DeLillo completed this novel just weeks before

Don DeLillo, the √©minence grise of American letters, has been writing about the intersection of technology and social disintegration for his entire career. In his first novel, Americana, the main character, David Bell, expounds on ‚Äúthe power of the image‚Äù and says stuff like ‚ÄúWe seemed to be no more than electric signals and we moved through time and space with the stutter and shadowed insanity of a TV commercial,‚Äù on his way to getting lost in the heartland trying to find an original American i

This is just going to be a random smattering of thoughts and questions on the book. I think it's certainly better than people give it credit for but it's not as good as what one expects from a Delillo book.

- It is deceptively short. The amount of time it would take total to read this is maybe 2-3 hours. I think it is that deceptive shortness that causes people to not pay attention to the hidden depths this book has. Yes, it is primarily a musing on technology and screen addiction/depe

Delillo really knows, I think better than anybody, how to ride the line between real and surreal, natural and supernatural. This one carves the line. He also knows how to produce an experience. He doesn‚Äôt tell a story, or a message, he gives us an experience.

The plot is pretty simple. Delillo alternates between two converging sets of characters experiencing the same event. Jim and Tessa are on an airplane, flying from Europe back to the US, scheduled to land in Newark. Dianne, Max, and Martin ar

In his latest slim novel, ‚ÄúThe Silence‚Äù (Scribner), DeLillo attacks technology and it‚Äôs domination over every aspect of our existence. The story begins in the near future of February 2022 on a transatlantic flight from Paris to New York. Jim Kripps, a claims adjuster, and his poet partner, Tessa Berens, are returning from a post-COVID vacation to Paris. Jim‚Äôs attention is glued to the overhead itinerary map when the plane loses power on its descent into Newark Airport. A crash landing sends Jim

It is Super Bowl Sunday in New York City, two years in the future. A man and wife, middle aged and well educated, are having a small gathering in their apartment to watch the game. One guest, a former student of the physics professor wife, has already arrived and another couple will be coming as soon as their plane from Paris lands. But just as the game is starting, the power inexplicably goes out along with all other means of electronic communication, throwing the world into a chaotic, albeit s

The Silence by Don DeLillo is a compact and sparse meditation on our digital connections, both to the world at large and our fellow human beings.

This is the type of book, really more of a novella than a novel, that will be hit or miss with most readers. It consists largely of monologues, delivered to others who may or may not be listening. That aspect alone will turn some readers off, there is nothing going on, well, except for the fact the world seems to have gone quiet, at least digitally.

There are places on a bookshelf for disappointing works by great authors, but flimflam must give way to waving cats. I should have known by the weight of the Amazon box that I had been had. If I did not suffer from optimism bias, the dust jacket would have given it away; the stipulation ‚ÄúA NOVEL‚Äù need not follow the title unless there is cause for misunderstanding. Review of The Silence by Don DeLillo

DeLillo is an influential modern American writer known for his past novels Underworld and White Noise, among others. The Silence writes about five people gathering for the Superbowl in 2022 when a catastrophe hits.

DeLillo finished this book just before the COVID-19 pandemic struck, and his novel of life in crisis is strangely prescient.

DeLillo, like Irving or Moody or even Salinger, writes about the nihilism and coldness at the heart of the educated upper midd

The reviews on this site have been polarizing. I won't claim others "don't get it," but I do think many were expecting something else, something more involved. I see DeLillo as a Beckett for the digital age, and as such, and as a fan of Beckett, I went into this book with that expectation in mind, and it mostly delivered. At the very least I was enthralled with the prose, and the sort of odd and detached nature of the characters, and I was so entertained that I read the book in a single sitting

DeLillo still knows how to write a damn good sentence. I doubt I'm the only one who was hoping he had another "Underworld" style epic in him, but "The Silence" isn't it. Wouldn't even call it a novella let alone a novel, it reads more like the introduction to a dystopian epic.

*slight spoilers ahead*

February 2022. A retired physics professor and her husband are hosting a Super Bowl game watch party on the Upper East Side of New York. One of the guests, the professor's former student, has already arrived, while two others are flying home from Paris and hoping to land in time to see most of the game. I have read excellent books by Don DeLillo but was very disappointed by this. Although marketed as a novel, it would be only a not-too-long short story. This is a novella nominated for several awards and I know why.

In this story, a security robot breaks its own company protocol, freeing itself from any restraints, thus allowing its personality to unfold. Through the eyes of "Murderbot" (she's named herself that way), we experience what it is like to work with and for humans, that humans come in all forms (good and bad and everything in between), what the company creating these robots programs them to do (and what not) - and, ultimately, we lear

Murderbot doesn't want to murder anyone.

Murderbot just wants to be free.

Free to binge-watch soap operas.

Is that too much to ask?
Murderbot is an incredible character. I super empathized with the bot from the first paragraph of the novella. All the bot wants is do to watch TV. Stop making it shoot stuff and protect weak humans!

This is the first in a series of science fiction novellas which I kept seeing mentioned by other readers. So of course I had to give it a try.

The story tells of an Artificial Intelligence which has been smart enough to hack itself and disengage the master controls. Now it works in security and calls itself a Murderbot. Bored with its existence it whiles away the time watching TV soaps in between and while on jobs. On this particular mission though the humans are empathetic and our self titled Mu

Murderbot is a part robot, part human construct designed to function as Security for humans. They are a bit different from most of the Company SepcUnits becuase they have modified themselves to take out the control that the Company and the humans have over them, but they know that this is incredibly dangerous for them and so they have to keep this hidden and just pretend to still be functioning as they should.

I really liked the character of Murderbot as it's really quite a grump when it comes to
Snarky robots are like catnip to me. Turns out Martha Wells is pretty funny.

The audio read by Kevin R. Free is superbly read and a lot of fun. He captured Murderbot's personality almost exactly how I had imagined it.

Having less time for leisure reading nowadays novellas are just the thing to avoid taking too long to read just one book. So I found All Systems Red, a novella that won both the Hugo and Nebula awards, this seemed a just the thing. ‚Ä¶ But is it? Yeah, it is.

The novella‚Äôs title intrigued me, in a clickbaity kind of way. As it turned out the ‚ÄúMurderbot‚Äù part of the title is just about the only thing I do not like about this (e)book. I feel that it is not representative of what the book is about, wh

Many books are written about the idea of an android becoming sentient. Not many of those books are good.

This one rocks!

If you know about an assassin droid HK-47 from the Star Wars universe and you liked him and his twisted sense of sarcasm - you will love every second (err.. page?) of this book. If not, it doesn't really matter.

Not so much cynical sarcasm here as much as a healthy dose of android humor. I leave it up to you to decide how much exactly is a healthy dose. I had a blast.

This book offers glimpses of what I find to be a fascinating world, but unfortunately, it is too short to fully explore all of its potential. Emma Bailey is living a great life, up for her final rotation in the London Police force detective training programme she gets assigned to the Supernatural Squad (usually given as a punishment for the truly useless) rather than the Cyber Crime assignment she (and her accountant boyfriend Jeremy) was expecting.

At first Emma is mortified at being given the dunce assignment, then excited at the idea of being a liaison between the humans, vampires and werewolves, complete with special cool weapons.

Emma is about to finish the last two weeks of her police department training. She has done exceedingly well and expects her next rotation to be in the cyber crime unit, only she ends up assigned to the supernatural squad. The tale that unfolds leads to murder and enlightenment.

Emma is a young detective-in-training with the London Police, just entering her last rotation before the final exam. Was good. It takes place in the world as we know it... just with some 'extra's' in the form of supes. Vampires, werewolves and Others (pixies, gremlins and such).

Scenes and environments were clear and well detailed.

Character development:
Was good. Emma (or D'Artagnan if you will) was an interesting character who pretty much got thrown to the wolves

I love Helen‚Äôs work. She‚Äôs among my favourite authors for this genre. There‚Äôs always an interesting storyline, an intelligent female lead and a potential love interest - in this case Lukas the head vampire. This book did not disappoint and I read it in one sitting. If I could, I would wait and read the whole series together but I just have to read the books as soon as they come out. I always remember the plot from the previous book which is testament to how good the writing is

One issue

It was extremely distracting for the author to use apostrophes in place of quotemarks, especially since she had never done this before in other books I have read by her. Maybe it is a British style of writing but I found following the dialogue harder. It won't keep me from reading her books, but it will require more effort for someone used to traditional written dialogue. I really enjoyed the novel and will read the rest of the series, but an edit to this would be kind.

Normally, a book like this would be perfect for my genre tastes, but I really struggled getting through it.

I would disagree with my book/reading club friends about what we thought was round the corner (aka next chapter) and there were so many cliche elements.

Where this book shows it's strengths, is how it added little flavour texts really made the world more vivid with my mental picture.

My only gripe... I‚Äôm tired of this constant troupe that Harper always employs... heroine unwittingly/unknowingly meets a mysterious guy that she instantly has chemistry with. Time goes on and she discovers that this guy is some head honcho-badass type that wants to help her save the day and then they of course fall in love.

It was OK, neither glowingly good nor horrendously bad. This is an illustrated novella following the events that occur after both the His Dark Materials trilogy and the other short story that follows it, Lyra's Oxford. This focuses on the series' central character, Lyra Belacqua, but her daemon, Pan, also shares equal focus. Other characters from the preceding books also feature, either physically or in speech, and much of what has previously occurred between them is mentioned.

This tiny story, set between The Amber Spyglass and The Secret Commonwealth, sets up the main conflict in the latter book: what happens when a person and their d√¶mon (essentially, a person and their own soul) are divided betweeth themselves. The story doesn‚Äôt provide answers, but frames the issue. "You know, it isn't really surprising that there are things about ourselves that still remain a mystery to us." I can't think of a better thematic prologue for The Secret Commonwealth.

Reading through this copiously illustrated story I was reminded of the great reading adventure that was His Dark Materials. How pleasant to meet an older and changing Lyra and Pantalaimon, and to find brief mentions of other beloved characters. This is a fast read, loaded with evocative illustrations. But the story feels fragmentary, portending something bigger which is apparently The Book of Dust, a series I have not read.

A delightful and well-presented little book. Serving as a quasi-prelude to The Book of Dust, Serpentine provides a fading glimpse into a brief time when Lyra and Pantalaimon are trying to understand their new "severed" freedom from each other. Unfortunately, this story is nothing new. Pullman admits as much in his note at the end of the book. It was written many years ago after His Dark Materials was published. However, it is likely this was not published previously due to its length. But after the recent success of the The Book of Dus

It concentrates on the relationship between Lyra and Pan following the events of the end of the original trilogy. The tensions in this relationship are the central theme of The Secret Commonwealth.

Small and sleek and sly and lovely: a little like Pan, and a little like Lyra, a sweetmeat - maybe a bittersweetmeat? - from Pullman. A brief episode after The Amber Spyglass and before La Belle Sauvage wherein Lyra and Pan think about their separation, not so much how it worked as how it felt. The linocut illustrations by Tom Duxbury are stark and spare but beauteous in their linear clarity.

If only this were longer...but, still, a gem of a story. Fortunately, my library had a free eBook available, so I could enlarge the illustrations and study them. They depict a more somber Lyra, no longer a bold child, heedless of others' expectations, but an awkward, self-conscious teen, caught up in grief after her separation from Will and stumbling forward without the comfort of consulting the alethiometer for expeditious guidance. Serpentine is a short story that acts as a small bridge between The Amber Spyglass, the last book in Philip Pullman's His Dark Materials trilogy, and The Secret Commonwealth, the second book in The Book of Dust, Pullman's followup to HDM. While there isn't much story development in Serpentine, it does show the beginnings of a major theme that we see throughout The Secret Commonwealth. A wonderful glimpse into Lyra and Pan's lives after the events of the His Dark Materials trilogy.

Lyra and Pan have never had secrets before, but Lyra can't stop thinking about what Pan might have done while they were separated, and isn't sure if it's okay to ask him. The Serpentine is a story about friendship, honesty, and knowing yourself.

Philip Pullman's Serpentine is a very short story, where we learn a little more about teenage Lyra's complicated relationship with her daemon, Pantalaimon, through a conversation Lyra has with Dr. Lanselius. Lanselius has an unusual relationship with the witches Lyra discovered in His Dark Materials, and the conversation foreshadows the conflict that will occur between Lyra and Pantaliamon. A series of illustrations by Tom Baxter, done as linotypes, are beautifully evocative. Too short by half,

This is another of Pullman's slim stop-gap short stories between the big books. It is set between The Amber Spyglass and the Secret Commonwealth, and shows the author toying with the new dynamic of Lyra being able to separate from her daimon, Pan.

The previous 'short story books' - Once Upon a Time n the North' and 'Lyra's Oxford' had plot and depth - this one much less so. One cannot help but feel that the reader is being exploited in being lured to buying a 'quality hardback' containing such a

I wouldn't ordinarily listen to the Philip Pullman audio before I read the actual book, but this just came out, and it was time for it, chronologically, to be heard. Unlike other volumes, this isn't done like a full radio play, but there is zero reason to complain, as it is read by the magnificent Olivia Colman.

Lyra, on an archeological expedition in the North, makes a visit to an old friend to discuss her relationship with Pan. It fits like a perfect puzzle piece between Lyra's Oxford and The

I hate to say it but I'm disappointed. I did really like the front cover and the artwork however the actual story it's self seemed to be a bit pointless It wasn't really a story at all. It is simply a short conversation that should be a tiny part of another story. It didn't really add anything to either the original or the new trilogy. I've read the other short stories and enjoyed those but this one wasn't worth paying the price of a full sized book for a 10 minute (if that) read.

Actually 3.5 stars, but rounded down for the reasons below:

1. I genuinely don't like woodcuts. They are too fussy looking.
2. The book is very short and takes place before the new series, so it seems almost irrelevant. It really doesn't get the characters anywhere new. I would rather have had his "The "Collectors" if I am paying so much for so little. At least that story fills in some interesting and unknown history.

So beautiful. My only issue with it is that it is so short. But it gives a beautiful insight into Pan‚Äôs and Lyra‚Äôs relationship between His Dark Materials and The Secret Commonwealth. And the illustrations are so well made and fitting to the story. When I turned the pages and there was little puppy Pan I felt a gut-punch of sadness and it was just like I imagined it. So very well done little story. Loved it.

To echo a fair few of the other reviews:69 pages (around half of which are illustrations), 15 minutes to read; ¬£5.50.

But moving beyond that... I'm not never going to read a book from Pullman's His Dark Materials universe, and the illustrations are very pretty!

Set between the Amber Spyglass and The Secret Commonwealth, this further the links between the trilogies and helps to explain the changing relationship between Lyra and Pan.

Am still waiting for Will's book :)

A further grown Lyra, of around 15 years of age, takes part in an archeological dig in the North in order to visit the place where she first met Iorek. She has the opportunity to sit down for a conversation with Dr Lanselius and discuss the relationship between a person and a daemon when they have once been separated. She also has an important conversation with Pantalaimon about their relationship.

It's really a very little story, like a chapter with lovely illustrations. Not necessary, but very much part of the HDM world. Fits in where ypu would imagine it to. Don't seek the book if you don't love the world and want just a bit more from it, because you won't really find a new adventure, just a new little idea.

Enjoyed this novella that connects his dark materials with the book of dust through Lyra's exploration into why she is able to do actions others can't. It is easy to read and focuses on Lyra's understanding of herself. The illustrations are also great, making it really accessible. I am so pleased that this book has been released after 16 years. A must for all fans of Phillip Pullman's writing.

That was such a quick read. Too short a read for that price. It really is a very small story when you take the illustrations into account. It's nice dialogue, really, and that's mostly because I've always been in love with the concept of daemons... But it feels like it should be a chapter in a bigger book.

I read the original His Dark Materials so long ago that I don't remember as much as I'd like, so getting back into the world of Lyra with this short story was really nice. I definitely want to reread the whole series again, as well as finally getting to La Belle Sauvage. The note at the end by Philip Pullman is really nice, too. ‚ô°

With the knowledge that Lyra's story continues in The Book of Dust, I was able to appreciate Serpentine as an interesting, quick insight into Lyra's life after His Dark Materials. There's nothing earth shattering in this, but if you love these characters, you will probably enjoy it as a fun, super-quick read that takes you back to their world. The illustrations are lovely as well.

With thanks to Penguin Random House, Netgalley & Philip Pullman for my ecopy in exchange for an honest review.

This was a really short story which picks up after the events of The Amber Spyglass. It was a nice little read which explored Pan & Lyra‚Äôs feelings towards one another after these events and a nice dip back into the world of His Dark Materials.

The influence on Lyra of those god-awful books and their horrible writers must've been stronger than I thought. She still seems very rational, decent person here, unlike the unlikable asshole she becomes by 20 years old in The Secret Commonwealth. I thought this lacked the heft of the previous two mini books spun out of His Dark Materials. The illustrations are exquisite.

3 stars only because it‚Äôs really short and not a lot happens. I listened to the audio version but I have since learned that the paperback is illustrated so it seems I‚Äôm missing the full experience. His Dark Materials are my favourite books of all time so I was so excited for another little glimpse into Lyra and Pan‚Äôs world. It was nice to hear from them again, I just wish it was more.

As much as I was waiting for this story, it surprisingly didn't add much to the overall narrative. I can easily see how this glimpse fits after His Dark Materials, but I still can't see how Lyra and Pan moved from there to how we see them in the Books of Dust. Anyway, can we have the third Book of Dust already?

I requested this from my library instead of buying it, and I'd say that was the right move. It's definitely an interesting story and it was nice to read as I wait for the last book in the Book of Dust trilogy. However, I'm not sure it adds much after The Secret Commonwealth. It does make The Secret Commonwealth even more sad though!

A nice wee read set between HDM and TBoD. A good gift for fans of the books but don‚Äôt get too excited as it can be read in about 10 mins! Always nice to get more Lyra though. If you haven‚Äôt read the entirety of His Dark Materials though steer well clear of this until you‚Äôre done because massive spoilers abound.

I really enjoyed reading this story, and as always it fits into the storyline perfectly. My only complaint is that it felt a little bit rushed - the other two short stories felt more like excerpts from a much longer book whereas this felt like a real short story. Maybe I'm just greedy because I can't get enough of these stories and I can't wait for the last in the new trilogy.

A charming story to bridge the gap between series' about Lyra. There's very little by way of plot progression or revelation about the world here. Just a meditative snapshoy of one afternoon in Lyra's life after the Amber Spyglass concludes. Feels more like post-novel bonus material than a stand-alone publication.

To be honest, this felt like a pretty pointless flash fiction read, but I love this world and these characters too much to give it less than 3 stars. Definitely something to flip through if you‚Äôre a super-fan, but not an independent way to introduce yourself to Lyra‚Äôs world.

Beautiful episode

Just beautiful, it‚Äôs so lovely to be back in this world that has given me so much joy for so many years!
I cannot wait for the third and final book in the Book of Dust trilogy!

Always nice to dip back into the world of Lyra, a quick read to keep us warm before Book Three of the Dust Trilogy. Not too much happens, some chat between Lyra and her Daemon, but Pullman's prose just slides off the page as usual. Very nice.

This is a nice story returning to much loved characters and with lovely illustrations, but it really is extremely short - literally a 10 minute read - so to price it at ¬£7.99 meant that I was just left feeling a bit ripped off. A real shame since I'm a huge fan of the original trilogy (especially).

I am not sure how I feel about this story. First, I thought it was a novella. It is not. But I like the story. My quibble is with the marketers who put it out as different than it is. It is a beautiful and beautifully illustrated short story.

‚ÄùYou know, it isn‚Äôt really surprising that there are things about ourselves that still remain a mystery to us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMaybe we should be comforted that the knowledge is there, even if it‚Äôs withheld for a while.‚Äù

ANYTHING by Philip Pullman is worth reading! Even his short stories. IF I didn't already have my hands full with my own life, I would have loved having a Daemon partner. This book is well worth the small amount of time it takes to read it and I highly recommend it as much as the author's novels.

A book for the superfans that are happy with even a modicum of new content. It really is a short book but if you like His Dark Materials and The Book of Dust then its a fun read and it gives a little context to The Secret Commonwealth.

A fairly inconsequential snippet for ¬£7.99 but it does at least drag you back into the space between Lyra and Pan in which we inhabit as readers of His Dark Materials. Adds nothing to the story hut does make a neat and comfortable link between the two trilogies.

A very short addition to the His Dark Materials & The Book of Dust Trilogies, rather like Lyra‚Äôs Oxford. It provides more background information but crucially wets the appetite for the next full length addition to the canon.

I just can't get enough of Lyra and Pan and their world. This is such a lovely little peek into the time between the end of HDM and The Secret Commonwealth. A gap that needed plugging - just like my insatiable need for more of this world.

I‚Äôm a complete sucker for anything about Lyra. Though it is short I really enjoyed it. The linocut illustrations are beautiful & the book itself is nicely bound with a dark green hardcover and ochre endpapers. Aesthetically pleasing on all fronts.

Very very short, but about half the contains some nice wood cut illustrations. Fills a gap between His Dark Materials and The Secret Commonwealth, but like most in-series novella (eh. In the Expanse books), it isn't necessary reading and only adds texture.

Oops!...I thought this was the third book in The Book of Dust trilogy. Alas, it isn't. At just 69 pages of well-spaced print and lots of lino-type pictures, this hardly rates even being called a novella. Still it was delightful to read, and the prints are beautiful.

This wasn't revelatory or necessary at all, except to reinforce how much I've come to dislike Lyra, in all her haughty petulance, as she's gotten older. I really wish I hadn't ventured into the new trilogy because it's tainting my love of the original.

Nice little story written years ago before Pullman decided to go back into the world of His Dark Materials. It's an interesting parallel to where we left Lyra and Pantalaimon in The Secret Commonwealth. I'm still anxiously awaiting the third installment in The Book of Dust.

A very quick visit to Lyra and Pan briefly back in the Arctic in the time following the Amber Spyglass.
This short story is worth the investment for the beautiful woodcut illustrations throughout.
An aperitif to keep the Pullman fans sweet until the next full length offering.

I just want lyra and pan to get on

4.5 stars

Squeeeee! I have lost all semblance of objectivity when it comes to these novellas. Bujold always delivers a wonderful mix of mystery, adventure, and theology; all balanced with a clear and compassionate view of the humans involved. I always come away feeling comforted.

Shows us a previously unknown time in Penric's life filling in some of the unknowns in both the world building and his journey. I love how Bujold has embraced self publishing e-novellas; there are nine in this series now and the journey as a whole is delightful.

Going to be honest, this feels like a bit of a dud compared to the previous novellas, especially the magnificent Orphans of Raspay. Still not *bad* (it's Bujold), but the central problem doesn't feel quite as pressing or the antagonists quite as dangerous.

I liked this a lot. It was a fun little adventure with a happy ending. I liked the new characters we met and would not mind seeing them again. Another fantastic entry in the Penric and Desdemona novella series. This made me think of Penric and the Shaman due to the adventure style to it plus it's place in the series and overall world.

This story introduces followers of Penric to a new city (Lodi), a new and different demon, and a new and different saint. The story is basically simple: Penric is presented with a problem, he gets help from the saint, and then solves it. It's just a brief incident in his life, with no lasting effect on him. However, we find out more than we knew before about the problems of demons, saints, and sorcerers; so in some ways it's an educational incident.

The latest novella in the Pen and Des series. This one comes between "Penric‚Äôs Fox" and "Penric‚Äôs Mission" so really should be labelled 3.5, but I noticed it was "book 4" in the digital copy I read and Goodreads calls in #9. That should confuse everybody. Even though it could be considered standalone, it really does help to have read all the others. It's another slice of low fantasy set in a 24 hour period and is up to the usual standard of the books in this series; both the dialog (internal and

Short but good!

This story seemed a bit shorter than some of the other Penric tales. Or maybe it was that I didn't want it to end.

The city of Lodi was wonderful, full of interesting sights. And boats. Lots of boats. I suspect it is based on a version of Venice.

Penric ends up chasing down a rogue demon on what should be a holiday. Some things are not quite what they seem.

It isn't really a mystery story, although there is a crime or two. There aren't really any clues.

Also one of my favorite bits is

Hardworking boy meets a nice girl. How that happens in one particularly action packed day is the magic of this story and this author. As others have mentioned, Lodi feels like an otherworldly Venice, and for anyone who has ever gotten lost wandering the streets of Venice, this story has a special fillip. Plus plenty of magic, adventure, demons and dastards. And with all due respect to one of my other favorite authors who is also a LMB fan, I didn't think it was too short. Iam very satisfied with

Brilliant, and so nice to spend time with characters I love.

Penric is asked to check on a madman, and discovers that he is not mad, but demon ridden. Penric does not have the gifts to rescue him, but he knows how to find someone who does.

This book introduces a couple of excellent new characters, a mystery, a heroine, and a romance. That‚Äôs a lot to put into a novella, but under LMB‚Äôs skilled hand it flows along and carries the reader with it.

This short novella is book 9 of the Penric and Desdemona series. This book is set earlier in Penric's life when he has only been with Desdemona for a few years. Penric is asked to look at a captured madman and all the events of the book trigger from that. A little bit of mystery as is the usual for these books. Overall I liked it though next time I read through the whole series I should not read this in book publication order.

A joy to read

While this is the latest novella in the pernicious and Desdemona series, it actually falls earlier in the series chronologically. It‚Äôs always fun to glimpse another part of penric‚Äôs and desdemona‚Äôs adventures. This was just as good as the others in the series, without being quite as heart wrenching as some of the more recent installments in the series. Well worth the read.

The latest Penric and Desdemona novella is actually set earlier than the last few, but while I was a little disappointed not to see Penric's family, I did like it a lot. It finds Penric, accompanied by a wry young Saint, on the trail of a possessed man. Solid plot and great characters. I always enjoy the Penric-Desdemona interchanges. A-.

I was so pleased to read another book in the Pen & Des series! It was interesting to slip back into Penric's past, and I almost wish I had re-read the series from the beginning to read this in its internal chronological timeline. But who can wait that long to read a new Lois McMaster Bujold book?! Certainly not me.

I just found this new Penric, after grumbling to myself about the lack of stories that are fun, warm, and about characters that can be cared about. As always, just a delight. For a fast reader, they end too quickly!

If. ... you found this Penric, first; strongly suggest you go back to the beginning story in the series.

I feel like the only real response to this is Animal from the Muppets cheering "More Penric, more Penric!"
I like how these novellas just suddenly appear (I mean, yes, Bujold WRITES them, but from my perspective it's as though I look around and there's suddenly a new addition to the story, which is quite delightful).

It‚Äôs always fun to revisit the World of the Five Gods, and Pen and Des are enjoyable company. This particular installment provides them with a mystery to be solved, which they do‚Äîbut not as easily as I did, making it fall a bit short in that department. Another fantastic installment in the Penric and Desdemona series, this one a flashback story to Pen's younger days. Here's hoping that Blessed Chio, older, wiser and even more formidable, turns up again in later installments.

This latest story in the Penric & Desdemona series fits in as book #4, even though there are other stories that have already been written that are chronologically set later. I love this series.

While the story can be read on its own, I strongly recommend starting at the start.

Delightful!

I've always loved Venice-like settings. As with most Penric stories, his relationship with his demon Desdemona and the locals is heartwarming. This is a lighter book, more relaxed, so please do read and enjoy!

Summary: Another really good novella, Penric at his best

Plotline: Simple but works on many levels with a few twists.

Premise: 5 gods. Complicated. Love it.

Writing: Excellent as always

Ending: Very satisfactory

Pace: Never a dull moment!

Learned Penric and a teenage Saint of the Bastard pursue an insane demon thru the night of the Bastard's festival on Lodi, forestalling a murder, healing a robbery victim, aiding in a potential romance, and possibly saving a soul.

Wonderful series of novellas

Romance, small village mysteries, religion & fantasy all wrapped up in beautifully smooth writing. This series is a writer having fun at the height of her craft.

It's always a pleasure to spend a few hours with Pen & Des. . . although I would have enjoyed seeing more of Des.

Chio is a wonderful new character, and I hope that she will make an appearance in future volumes of this series.

Another excellent novella with Pen and Des

This is set between Penric‚Äôs mission and the story prior. It is an interesting story that introduces another saint of the 5th god and a new setting reminiscent of Venice.

It is rare for me to give any book by Lois McMaster Bujold less than five stars. She is easily one of the best F&SF writers writing today. My problem with this book is that there is so little to it. It feels like one chapter of a longer book.

Still great - recommend

I can‚Äôt tell you why I liked this one so much. Expected tight plot with pleasing twisty bits and humour. There‚Äôs something comforting about a character trying hard to do their best and messing it up and it all being ok in the end.

5 stars just for the joy of getting to spend a little more time with Penric and Des, this time in the Venice-inspired city of Lodi. We meet a young saint, brave danger, and solve a mystery. It's a lovely world to visit, and a perfect escape!

Another fix

Honestly, I love her work so much that this review is redundant. She's a brilliant writer and we now get regular supplies of her work and I'm very happy about that. More please!

What can I say I love this series, the characters are great and the stories are accessible, easy reads and very entertaining. This one takes place in between others in the series so should really be #3.5
I find these novellas so charming. I adored the glimpse into the life of a Saint.
Fun! I hope Penric keeps up a correspondence with Chio.
Lovely novella, highly recommended. Probably the first Penric novella is needed for full appreciation as there's no world building in this fantasy story.
Delightful snippet in the life and adventures of Pen & Des.
Just another delightful little low stakes Pen and Des adventure.

Another Outstanding Story

Another Delightful read. I truly enjoy the glimpse into this world. Please don't stop the return visits to this enchanting world.
A wonderful little morsel of a story. Penric and Des!
A goodnatured little novella with more demonic goings on. Note that this takes place early in the series.

A sorcerer and a saint

We get to see the experience of being a saint, as Penric teams up with one to eject a twisted demon... if they can find it! A very good Penric story.

Good story

A short novella. Not the best Penric novel but entertaining characters as always. This could be a stand alone novella.
Hrm I enjoyed this though it was a bit muddled compared to the last.
I never read a LMB story I did't like. Thank you, Lois!
another enjoyable stroll with Des and Penric.
Pen and Des, newly arrived in Lodi. Lovely.

Gently psychological

Feels like home inside Penric‚Äôs head, Des is both a critic Mother and friend, and funny as well as clever
Always such a joy to read. I love these two.

A lovely little distraction as usual. A little sad I'm caught up and there's only one left! I really loved the character development of the saint, it was concise and clear, and the story ended with a great sense of humor. Those are all the best parts of this series.
Another fun Penric adventure. It was nice to move away from the more recent storyline and have an unconnected story.

Excellent, as always

I don't think she's capable of writing a poor story and I very much enjoyed this one. More, please? Whenever you can...
Wonderful feel-good read.

The release of this story during the worldwide shutdown for the corona virus was a masterful way to remind us to be sensible instead of fearful in a time where fear, uncertainty and doubt may never have had greater pull for less reason worldwide. J.K. Rowling has proven once again her deep understanding of human nature. It's refreshing to see her release children's literature.

A great lesson in courage (Daisy, Mrs.Beamish), honesty (Lady Eslanda) and how actions speak louder than words (how Ickaboggle bornded cruel and kind).
I'd love to read this story to my child someday.
Really liked J.K. Rowling's "The Ickabog" and was a fun new type of fairytale. :) Very cool getting to read chapters online every Monday-Friday for the past couple months and see how this story went.

I really enjoyed reading this. Not a tale for the very young, more in the style of classic fairy tales like the Grimm brothers' tales, in that it definitely has its darker moments, but I couldn't stop reading it. I eagerly awaited each new chapter!

I really enjoyed reading it in the evening before going to bed. A shame that I‚Äôm not allowed to enter the competition but will be very happy to see all the wonderful contributions made in the publication at the end of the year.

I thought this was a darling, engaging, quick read. It was definitely a page-turner for me to see what happened next. It's written for younger audiences so the pages were easy and turned quickly with little thought. A delightful distraction.
I loved it the most. The story line was unpredictable and amazing
Really enjoyed. Cried 7x while reading it to my husband.
Such a fun little read!
Love it! I am going to buy it to read aloud to my class. It's all about the power of kindness.

This book is amazing and there are turns in the plot wherever you are. I love it

The Ickabog is a lovely story for children. However, keep in mind that, although the language is easy to understand and the lessons simple, there are topics such as death, abuse, treason, and more. Just like in the old fairytales, you know?

J.K. Rowling's new story came as a surprise to many, for after so many years of saying she wouldn't write for children anymore, no more magic, no more fantasy - she did publish the story of the marshland monster - the Ickabog.

Personally, I was disappointed. It lacked the humour that I love in the Potter books, and it lacked the style of the Galbraith novels. It felt hurried, and perhaps because of the nature of how it was released it was.

I really, really liked the Ickabog bits...and for me as the

For 7 weeks each night as the story unfolded, there was something to look forward to every day. While the book might be a bit too dark in some places for it to be called a children's fairytale, it can be read and enjoyed by people of all ages. There were days when

3.5/5 stars

This is a fairytale whose intended audience is young children, despite that, it can be enjoyed by any age group.
As we have already seen J K Rowling's imagination power in the Harry Potter series, she doesnt disappoint here as well.
From the description of the land of Cornucopia to the monster Ickabog everything in the story is very detailed. Though the plot of the story is very simple but it keeps you wanting to read more to know where the story will go on.

Part of me wants to give this 5 stars. I mean, for the past several weeks a highlight of each weekday has been to visit the Ickabog website and to delve deeper into this thoughtful, well written children's fairy tale. J. K. legit had me hooked.

Alas, I'll push as much bias aside as possible, and simply say that this was a really solid read.

Fantastic second book in this brilliant series!

loved it. Not sure where to start and don‚Äôt want to spoil for anyone. I will say that Ivy House is definitely an interesting entity lol. Those dolls give me the wiggles. This latest book in the Leveling Up series is wonderful. It's fast paced, keeping you on the edge of your seat, while developing great characters you will grow to care about. WOW

Hysterical

Another hit by KF Breene. I swear this woman is my spirit animal!

Distinguished with a side of crazy fabulous.

Jessie thinks that with inheriting her new magic, she should be able to fly. Everybody says so. The new gargoyle alpha who is big, strong, and very good looking, has weird ideas on how to bring that power out of her. Austin Steele thinks that the plan is terrible.
