Very entertaining

For some strange reason, Ms. Breene is a bit of hit or miss for me. I loved her first two series and then the next series was definitely a case of who cares. Then the next couple of series were definite hits. And so it goes. This Magical Midlife Dating is worth reading, and I certainly recommend it. I wait Book Three with breathlessness. You definitely need to read from Book One.

Absolutely wonderful

I love the way Queen Breene uses conversation between characters to tell the story. I love the humorous interactions between characters. She does not spend pages describing the inside of a room or a landscape like many authors do. She is able to give the reader a clear picture in just a few sentences. I love that! I can't wait for the next one. I really hope Jessie and Austin get together soon.

Wow, this book had me on a rollercoaster of emotions. I would be laughing hysterically in one chapter and then really fed up of the stupid,crazy antics of the lot of them in another scene. I gave it 4 stars because I love the concept but I really find Jess's constant whining and self analysis (that usually is self put-down) annoying. I truly like the house dynamics but the over-the-top craziness gets a bit much.

I do thoroughly enjoy the characters that Breene has created but it is the personality of Ivy House that keeps me coming back. This book was better than the first as we were able to get to know some of the characters better. Seeing Edgar's home and how he spends his time was not only humorous but also shared a vulnerability that we don't usually think about with vampires. Looking forward to more in the series.

Nice follow up of Jessy's new life as an immortal. It begins a little slow but as always it picks up speed and fluency as you continue reading. I just that these series develops because the story has a lot of plot and not because it'll take 10 books to finally see the main couple together.

Ugh

Fabulous and hilarious and action-packed and characters full of crazy and magic and -- enough already. Great fun to read and great follow-up to the first in the series (Magical Midlife Madness). Excellent

Reading this made me want to read The Illuminae Files all over again! It tells of the making of AIDAN as the villain/antihero AI I know it to be in the trilogy. Memento is an interesting look into the early stages of AIDAN right up until the attack at Kerenza IV, which kicks off Illuminae. It's structured exactly like the rest of the Illimunae books---via chats, video footage, transcripts, etc. Though short, we get to know Oliva through emails to her father, chats with her roomie, and conversations she has with AIDAN. This novella, by one of my favorite writing duos, Amie Kaufman and Jay Kristoff, is a VERY short story, coming in at a listening total of just over ninety minutes. But, it quickly packs a powerful punch. But be warned, true to their signature style, the authors created a story that will rip your heart to shreds.

Quick and fun. The premise comes from The Dispatcher: if you die any other way, you stay dead, but if you're murdered you have a 99.9% chance of not dying--you turn up in a safe place like your home, leaving your clothes and everything else behind at the murder scene. Our hero's a professional murderer, known as a dispatcher, but he's down on his luck and having to take jobs he'd ordinarily turn down.

This is a fun sequel to a novelette I didn't think we'd be getting a sequel to. I really enjoyed The Dispatcher, and was super excited to see that there was a second one. The plot twists in this one weren't really twists (if you've read the first book you can easily see hints of what's coming with the investigations) but I'm also not sure that they were supposed to be twists. I had no real surprises from this book, but it was an enjoyable listen and the narration was perfect.

This is a very interesting world, one where you cannot die of accidental means but only by natural causes or suicide. Well, you can still die but it's like a 1 in 1000 chance of it actually happening.

Love the mystery aspect of the series. It's closest cousin (that I've read) would be like Castle mixed with Dresden.

And I would be remiss if I forgot to mention Zachary Quinto as the narrator. He does a very good job with the book and suits the content very well.

If only every book were as good as this one. I love Scalzi in general, and this series in particular. Quinto's reading of the audiobook is flawless. Super excited to jump back into this world and it didn't disappoint. Overall a pretty quick tale but didn't feel rushed and the complications were fun and interesting.

Tony Valdez is serious and professional about his work as a Dispatcher, and normally tries to stick strictly to the legal and ethical side of the business. Times have gotten hard with the declining economy, though, and to keep paying the bills, he's had to take a few jobs that are a little shady.

This short audiobook is the sequel to The Dispatcher, a murder mystery set in a world in which anyone who is murdered returns to life at home unharmed. The protagonist, Tony, has a job in which he murders people who are about to die by other means so that they get a second chance. John Scalzi‚Äôs Dispatcher stories read a lot like Isaac Asimov‚Äôs famous I, Robot collection. In Asimov‚Äôs tales, the robots appear to do something that violates the three laws of robotics and the trick to the story is to figure out why they didn‚Äôt violate them. In Scalzi‚Äôs tale, murders appear to violate the understanding of the new rule of death‚Äîpeople who are murdered wake up alive and naked in their homes 999 out of 1000 times.

4.0 stars - 2nd installment of The Dispatcher, a mystery even better than the first.

Tony Valdez is a Dispatcher. Tony murders people to save their lives.

In our near future, suddenly it is nearly impossible to be murdered. If you die by accident or natural causes, you die and stay dead. However, if one is murdered, 999 times out 1000, the murdered person returns to life a moment later, back at home or other safe place, naked and confused.

John Scalzi and Zachary Quinto teamed up to give us another fun, noir-style mystery set in the Dispatcher's alt-reality! This takes place in the early 21st century in Chicago, where the Cubs still matter, and a world where murder has become pointless, due to some undefined, supernatural event allowing (only) murder victims, another life... and when they wake-up, they can simply call the police and point out the guilty party!

Scalzi manages to expand on the wacky rules of the Dispatcher universe in a lot of unexpected but logical ways, while also setting up a good mystery that makes good use of those rules. I also appreciate it when an author can admit the rules they set up don't completely work, and that use that discrepancy as a key to the plot. The line between murder and suicide is a central concept in this world where murdered victims almost always come back, but suicides do not.

My only challenge was that I got confused at the end. Had I stepped back, thought through it, and put it all together - I would have a better result.

Finally, the Quinto narration is, again, top notch.

This is a good sequel, I like the story and how it is developed. I did not particularly like the reader: Zachary Quinto is a dog actor, I enjoyed his movies but audiobooks are different, he has a nice deep voice but very monotone, he hardly differentiate characters and often does not use pauses and silence for dramatic effect, he flies over sentences and paragraphs that should not be meshed together. I would like to hear this series read by some else (or I may just buy the books instead)

Even better than the first novella in the series. While you could technically listen to this without having listened to the first, why would you when they are both so good? Exciting and more complex than most novellas. Love the concept surrounding this series‚Äî a nice blend of science fiction and mystery. And very nicely narrated by Zachary Quinto. I hope this becomes a continuing series. I highly recommend it.

Truly enjoying this series about a man whose job is to kill people so they don't really die, they wake up naked in their bed instead. This is a world in which people who are murdered or die by accident don't die; no one knows how or why it works but in 999 cases out of 1000, it does. So to actually murder someone and have it stick, alternative means must be devised. It's well written and smartly presented; it doesn't insult your intelligence. High props!

I enjoyed this novella by Scalzi, perhaps a little less than the original but still a lot. This story is more of a detective whodunit. I admire Scalzi's ability to take a ludicrous setup like the revival of the murdered and run with it in a thoroughly logical way turning what would normally look like fantasy and turn it into science fiction. As always his dialogue is fun, alive, and occasionally snarky. Good job.

Like most short stories in this genre, Murder by Other Means, leaves me flat. Why? Too short. Too transparent. And done too death by episodic television. As a follow up to The Dispatcher, I was intrigued though and tried it on a cold football and political ad filled afternoon. It was the transparency factor that knocked me out this afternoon. How did Valdez miss the stinking non red herring Scalzi plopped in the middle of the narrative? I thought he was smarter.

A very good follow up to 'The Dispatcher' again very well narrated by Zachary Quinto. I really enjoyed both stories a whole lot! This one got a little darker, but still with plenty of moment of levity and things that made me chuckle and even laugh out loud. The mystery itself is just intricate enough that you think you may know what is going on, only to find that there were a few more plot twists that I certainly did not see coming.

More please!!!

A better story than the first of the series. With the worldbuilding behind him, Scalzi can delve into the details of how people behave in the new murderless world and what it means to be a target for unsavory characters. As before, there is no real detective story, but rather things are explained to the main character by another character, but this time the main character takes some action that changes the flow of the story.

Scalzi is gaining a lot of points with me lately, even though I feel like this book was far to short. I'm giving it a 3/5 based on the fact that it was too short to for real character development and there needed to be far more exploration of the phenomenon the book was based around. The narrator, Zachary Quinto (Slylar on the show Heros) was beyond excellent and I will look for future audiobooks he has done.

I'm either in a great mood as I complete these reviews, or I just have been on a run of reading some really engaging books. This short story was close to perfect. Nothing felt rushed or forced, and you didn't feel shorted at all because of the length, which are two main problems with some of these shorter works. Zachary Quinto is outstanding as the narrator, and the story really pulls you in. This may have been better than the first one.

The mechanics of how the dispatching works and under which circumstances it does and does not take are still pretty fuzzy to me. It‚Äôs an interesting concept and the story itself was compelling, but I had so many questions about this major plot point that it detracted from my enjoyment of the story as a whole.

These audiobooks are a lot of fun, and I think the second one was even better than the first. The narrator does a great job voicing the laconic reluctant hero, who has the counterintuitive job of killing people to save their lives. The mystery is surprisingly layered and complex for such a short story.

I am so happy that there is more to the Dispatcher series. I really enjoyed the first one and I was very excited when I discovered that there was a second one. I really hope that there will be more after this. The narrator, Zachary Quinto, is fantastic! I think that I may actually like this sequel better than the first one. This book is totally worth the listen.

First one was better. I'm having a hard time describing my issue with the book but it is almost exclusively plot related. I can't summon the requisite suspension of disbelief necessary to buy into the world. Characters are interesting, dialogue is realistic, pacing is comfortable - but I just can't buy it.

Tony Valdez is back to murder people, so they don't die. But a Chinese businessman wants to use his services to travel quickly back to China to finish a business deal. Unfortunately, this leads to him being framed not only for a bank robbery but a series of murder/suicides across the north side of Chicago. The second book of speculative fiction noir thriller series.

The dispatcher concept in Scalzi‚Äôs first story was original and fun. Like an engineered magic system from a fantasy novel but without the magic.

The second installment returns us to Chicago and familiar Tony, the man in the new thankless role of dispatcher, there to help ensure people die the right way.

I enjoyed the story and look forward to the potential of a third installment.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, this was perfectly fine mystery novel if you like that sort of thing. 4 stars, at least. But it gets knocked a star for introducing a perfectly interesting sci-fi premise but not trying to explain it in ANY way. This is the gun that‚Äôs introduced in act 1. :P

I didn‚Äôt read the first one and I‚Äôm definitely not going to.

I enjoyed the first Dispatcher and this was equally as enjoyable. Zachary Quinto does a phenomenal job with the narration once again. This was a good detective story and kept me engaged. If you enjoyed the premise of the first book you'll enjoy this one as well.

Disclaimer: My enjoyment of the narrator is based on my listening speed. I only leave 5 stars for books I've listened to multiple times. I'll update my review if I listen again.

I was so happy to get another adventure in the Universe that is "The Dispatcher". Well done mystery with returning characters. This Universe intrigues me because no only can you not die through murder, but it creates villains that have to be creative when wanting to kill someone. Plus the first Dispatcher had me hooked.

A solid addition to the series. I had figured "The Dispatcher" was going to be a one-off, so this was a pleasant surprise. Effectively a Buddy Cop book, but its well written and doesn't lean into the stupid tropes of that sub-genre too much. Instead it manages to be both topical (through dialogue and general setting) and entertaining.

Murder by Other Means was fine, but I think its super far-fetched premise takes away from the book. I mean why do people come back from the dead when murdered? Magic, living in a simulation, it's all a dream. The plot feels like a Twilight Zone episode. However, it's free and Zachary Quinto narrates it, so it has that going for it. It is also super short.

The world that John Scalzi has created with the dispatcher is amazing. His grasp and explanations of the rules of his world are perfect. This book further explores the rules of the world and twists them aronud, making for an excellent story. While I enjoyed the first book better, this one still captured the feelings and themes of the first. Making for an easy, enjoyable read.

John Scalzi almost never disappoints when it comes to a short story, and this one is no exception. A sequel to one of his more interesting scenarios, this short story has all of his usual strong characterization, wit, and plenty of mystery. He could really show a lot of the top mystery writers out there a few things. An enjoyable listen.

Accidentally listened to this one before the first book, but it didn't matter a ton. Like the first book, I enjoyed the concept and enjoyed the listening. The plot in this one was especially intriguing with a good mystery. But it had too much swearing (and maybe a little too much blood) for me to happily recommend it to friends/family.

I think you need to read/listen to the first book The Dispatcher before venturing into this one. It started off weird like it was trying to tie in the first book but just came out awkward. It is still a good book even though some people don‚Äôt like the premise of the book, 999 out of 1000 people murdered come back to life and no one knows why.

Overall enjoyable, but I enjoyed The Dispatcher more. The premise of the plot was certainly intriguing ‚Äì how do you like someone in a world where murder victims are resurrected? The plot unraveled all at once in the final chapter, a little too quickly for my liking, but it was overall clever and an enjoyable quick read.

Second installment of the ramifications of not being able to be murdered.

Cool new concepts like if you don't feel safe/good at home, you don't appear there anymore but you end up somewhere else.

I can continue reading/listening to these books indefinitely. A great sci-fi take on cop/murder drama.

In the second (very) short story, this one continues the adventures of Tony from the previous short story.

This one was OK aside from the fact that the 'coincidence fairy' was way too obvious.

If I had stuff like this happen to me, I would begin to wonder if the world itself was a simulation. I get the author wanting to wrap everything up in a bow but geeze.

The second novella in the Dispatcher series, this one is more of a noir-ish mystery. Its premise is an expansion of the world building the first novella. How can the bad guys get rid of a victim when murder is not final? I enjoyed both the writing and the narration by Zachary Quinto. I hope there will be more to come.

I enjoyed this as a short installment in this crime series that I hope there will be more of. When the mystery wasn‚Äôt as worked out as I‚Äôd have liked, I enjoy a mystery we can solve along with the characters more, the premise is good as is the dialogue. Zachary Quinto‚Äôs narration is spot on and I really do feel he is the character.

Highly recommend this sequel to ‚ÄúThe Dispatcher.‚Äù

I thoroughly enjoyed this sequel to ‚ÄúThe Dispatcher,‚Äù and I fervently hope that John Scalzi will continue this as a series. Zachary Quinto is a fantastic voice actor, who is the perfect Tony Valdez, licensed dispatcher. Bravo, Mr. Quinto. Bravo!

4.5 stars

As a mystery, I feel like this actually does a better job of playing fair than the first in the series. And there‚Äôs a moment near the end, when I wasn‚Äôt sure what would happen, and ended up trying not to cackle aloud.

I am a fan of Scalzi's style, laced with humor but still addressing some serious issues this story was very enjoyable and engrossing. I'm not sure everyone will like Zachary Quinto's narration, but I enjoyed his read of some of the new characters specifically.

Entertaining and a quick read/listen and one of the "free with an audible membership" books. The weird thing is that I can't remember any of the plot details about The Dispatcher (1st book in series), though I do remember the scenario.

I always enjoy finding a sequel to a story I've already enjoyed. When I picked this one up, I didn't know it was connected to a story I'd read. It was great seeing this one unfold and furthering the story.

I enjoyed the premise and the way murder/death works.

Unfortunately I found it kinda unbelievable and slightly eye rolling.

The story also starts to shape like a typical murder mystery with tropes aplenty.

Cool premise but bland story

Quite a really good follow up to The Dispatcher which to be honest I liked a bit more, though this was a worthy successor. I just will go against the crowd and say that Zachary Quinto's narrating wasn't quite doing it for me, often sounding almost bored and dispassionate...

You know, I really enjoy these Dispatcher novellas. I think the world is interesting, I like main character Tony Valdez and his relationship with Detective Langdon, and I definitely enjoy getting to listen to Zachary Quinto read me books!

This was enjoyable. While it can stand alone, it is a follow up to The Dispatcher, so I suggest you go on ahead and read that one first. Both of these are quick reads and are a real thinking man's mystery.

I like it . Very interesting concept . If a person is murdered they completely vanish , no remains AT ALL . They then return to life naked in their home . This causes some very interesting situations .

I wanted more of this world and like magic Scalzi granted it. This one was not as difficult to solve early as the last, but I like the world and the mystery. How does one commit murder when the murdered always come back? I also really like Quinto as the narrator. More please.

Well, it's a story really. It's a pretty interesting story I guess, but it's very much like a fluff piece. There's not a whole lot of depth in the premise itself or any of the characters, however the plot is twisted enough that keeps you interested. Very mediocre book.

I didn't know there was a 2nd one until just like 2 weeks ago, so thanks to Angie for making me aware of that. I enjoyed this one as much as the first, would love more from this work and with these characters. Super fun, quick and enjoyable.

Pretty good sequel with some interesting ideas about how things could change from a thing we can't predict or control.
Really interesting ideas in this series and I really like that it's both grounded and at times wildly conceptual.

More of a story than a book - I listened to the last episode in this series ("The Dispatcher") and found the concept intriguing. The concept is still good (and I won't reveal it here), but the plot was fairly hackneyed and formulaic. It's like a detective novel that isn't that novel.

John Scalzi has a gifted imagination and the ability to create scenarios that are both entertaining and puzzling. I like the challenge of figuring out how society changes when murder means the victim comes back to life without harm, unless there's another way.

Story was interesting, tho the world building could have used some work. Budget cuts seemed way too unlikely of an external force for the main characters, while at the same time a market that supports another character having an empire of buildings dedicated as airbnb's.

The narrator performance was passable but not great.

Really liked it, maybe a 3.5 out of 5, but Scalzi through in just one too many convenient coinkydinks ("It's all connected!") for my liking. Still, I love the puzzle boxes he's thrown together in this universe; despite my criticisms I definitely couldn't stop listening.

This was a quick listen. Interesting concept of murdered people coming back to life 999 times out of 1000 making crime a bit complicated.
I did not realize this was a second book in a series, and I have not read the first book. It didn't really matter, as the story stood fine on its own.
a fantastic entry in what i hope will be a continuing series. tightly written and brilliantly read. i can't wait for the next one.
I really like this series and I hope there's more to come.

Quick listen. Great performance. Would love to see more in this series.

Would probably be a good movie.
I'm biased and I love Scalzi books. If you liked the first one there is no reason you wouldn't like this one.
I liked this a lot. It was not as good as The Dispatcher, but it was still very good. I'm looking forward to the next story in this series.
AWESOME!! Really great story! Keeps you on edge of your seat! Want more of Dispatcher!!
Another good Scalzi novela in the Dispatcher world. Keep them coming!

Love that he Scalzi has this story in his hopper for a novella when he has an urge to return to it.

Quick and fun read
2.5 stars. Overly long, not nearly as interesting as the first one.
New Scalzi is always welcome in my reading/listening library. I wish it were longer, as I do with all writings I enjoy, but the story comes to a satisfying conclusion.

Absolutely awesome sequel to the Dispatcher.

A really enjoyable listen and great narration by Zachary Quinto. The series is pretty intense and I hope Scalzi writes more of these.
I loved this even more than the first book. I hope that there will be more
Thoroughly enjoyed the diversity of characters. And it's pretty rare that I like A Mob Character but this one cracked me up. Could have been Quinto's A++++ performance, but still. Good times.
This is an engaging detective story and a premise that makes you think.
I thought this was a remarkably inventive and creative twist on the classic gumshoe murder mystery. I enjoyed it as I have enjoyed other John Scalzi books.
3.5 stars
Still a really neat world and these quick bite stories are good for it. Looking forward to more
I did enjoy the audiobook but it was a bit convoluted and tough to buy into all the connections. Enjoyable quick listen.
Included free with Audible Plus and just as freakin great as the first in the series! Wish each book was full length, but they're still delightful in any case. The narrator is perfect too.
Get this book. Dispatcher book 2 is Awesome.
This is a well-written, well-narrated mystery with a sci-fi twist. I look forward to more of the protagonist‚Äôs adventures.
Very entertaining and well done.
I really enjoyed the story and the narration. I‚Äôm also a sucker for novels set in Chicago. I‚Äôm waiting for another Dispatcher story!
A solid follow up. A decent mystery. Ok narration.
Great performance by Zachary Quinto, and I enjoyed the twistiness of a murder mystery set in a world where almost no one can actually be murdered.
Very good follow-up to the first book.
Very interesting premise. Good addition to the series.
Nice follow up to the Dispatcher. I really liked the voice of the actor.
Great follow up to "The Dispatcher." Nice blend of amateur Detective/Science Fiction. Scalzi doesn't disappoint!
Great short story in this fantastic universe, where people usually come back from being killed and so there are people that kill people as a profession in order to save their lives.
The Dispatcher series is great, hopefully we get a full novel one day!
These were surprisingly great reads!! Will look for more from this author.
A really good follow up to The Dispatcher. Intricate and well paced
Good story.

Short murder mystery, #2 of something I read earlier
John Scalzi has become once of the most read author now for me
I have read/listen the "Dispatcher" book and I really liked it. This one didn't disappoint too.
I always love Scalzi's characters.
Enjoyable, well plotted and good characterizations. Fun quick Sunday read.

We have a cleric named Chi (they/them) and their hoopoe Almost Brilliant who are listening to the story of the Empress In-Yo, who had Rabbit as a handmaiden during the time when she was married into an alliance, and then exiled. a story about a nonbinary monk looking to expand the annals of history, and the elderly lady who gives them a tale they will never forget.

I am keeping this short: I was confused most of the time, the writing was great but I finished while still trying to connect to the characters and story. I felt it was a bit choppy and disjointed. Still a fast feminist short story if you want want.

I'm always on the lookout for writers who are getting people excited, and this one graced my radar several times before I was able to grab her on Netgalley.

This one has some really cool setting descriptions (evocative and colorful), excellent use of object descriptions (telling very understated stories that branch much deeper than first implications), and some very cool points of subtlety in the telling of a much larger story.

In a nutshell, we hear the story of an exiled princess in a Chinese-l

Empress of Salt and Fortune is the best example of quiet fantasy I know. It's a story about a revolution, about the upheaval of an empire, the way many fantasy stories are - and yet it's unlike everything I've ever read. There isn't one fight scene, it's told decades after the events happened, and it relies so much on details and symbolism, as quiet fantasy does when it needs to talk about something not quiet at all.
It follows Chih (they/them), a cleric - who pretty much functions as a historian

"One drunken evening, many years on, In-yo would say that the war was won by silenced and nameless women, and it would be hard to argue with her."


Cleric Chih and Almost Brilliant, a hoopoe, travel to Lake Scarlett, where the compound that Empress In-yo was exiled to sits. Chih means to catalog the contents of the compound and record its stories, but when they arrive they are greeted by an old woman named Rabbit, who invites them in. The empress of salt and fortune is a short story about an exiled empress and her rise to power and her unconditional love for women.

While the whimsical writing style of this book enhanced the experience, turning the story into a fairy tale, there was little to anything else to this book.

The characters, while complex, were seen from distance, which made any kind of emotional connection impossible. The pacing of the story felt off, as th

A really excellent novella set in an Asian-inspired alt world, with a touch of magic but mostly politics and conspiracy and fantastic feminist rage. Haunting, extraordinary, deeply compelling in a quietly building way. Really really good.

This novella captures so much with seeming simplicity; I think that's the beauty of it.

I'm left suffused with wonder, and the feeling that I've just witnessed‚Äîlike Chih‚Äîa piece of a nation's history, and more importantly, the love and loyalty of one simple woman who did not turn out to be so simple after all.

‚òÜ 4 / 5 ‚òÜ

"It is beautiful, but every stitch bites into her history, the deaths she left behind her, and the home she could not return to."

This was truly a fantastic novella and had so much impact with so little pages.

We follow Chih, a cleric, and their magical hoopoe companion, Almost Brilliant, on their journey to the capital to witness the new Empress‚Äô first Dragon Court. On the way they meet Rabbit, a servant of the late Empress and record the stories she has to share.

‚ÄúI thought she w

A fairytale of fierce political females, cunning warriors and spies told in a highly evocative and almost whimsical way that truly captivates the reader to Rabbit's story of an exiled princess.

It's short, yes, and because of this a bulk of what would be considered the 'action' scenes are skipped over in favour of letting the reader simply enjoy the characters for what they are and what they become. It felt incredibly poignant and special, as though I was being given a rare gift from Rabbit in h

"Do you understand?"

When Chih and their hoopoe, Almost Brilliant, set out to archive the halls of Lake Scarlet, they meet Rabbit. The elderly Rabbit imparts the tale of In-yo, the empress she was once a handmaiden to. An empress she befriended and got far more than she bargained for.

Power did not come easy to In-yo, but now history will remember In-yo's power.

A story of symbolism and sorrow. A tale of subtle, never spoken words.

It took me a few chapters to get in to this story but once i did, it swept me off my feet.

Chih finds an old woman nicknamed Rabbit who allows them to stay, who recounts stories of being handmaiden to the Empress.

This was stunningly written. I was so enamoured with it I read it in about an hour. I love reading short stories but I especially love reading ones that pack just as much of an emotional punch as a full length novel.

Do you ever finish a novella and simultaneously you‚Äôre satisfied because it‚Äôs managed to tell a complete story but also you want to be living in that world for so much longer? Well, this is one of those.

The Empress of Salt and Fortune

It's not the notes that you play. It's the notes that you don't play that make the song. Empress is a stunning little puzzle box of a story. A cleric-historian named Chih visits a lake-side villa that has been declassified, removed from a sorcerous veil that blocked all interaction for decades. There she finds an elderly lady, Rabbit, once handmaiden to the titular Empress. The narrative plays out as Rabbit tells her memories, each prompted by an object found in the villa.

The story fragments ar

What a compressed gem! High drama without the dramatics and fireworks. I love the way the story unfolds through the uncovering of artifacts by Chih, a cleric from the Singing Hills abbey, and the explanation of their meaning by Rabbit, an old woman who is a caretaker of the house on the Scarlet Lake. Empress of Salt and Fortune reads like a rich, engaging answer to the tiresome-yet-persistent question: "Why does it matter what color skin the writer has/which bathroom they use?"etc. Through complex fantasy, Nghi Vo beautifully illustrates exactly how where the writer comes from matters (to be clear, I mean where she's coming from in her *essence* [for lack of a better term] - I don't mean "the shores of Lake Michigan," which according to her bio is where she actually lives.)

"She did not promise to make it up to me, because there was no such possibility, and she did not say that everything would be all right, because it never would be."



This book is unlike anything I typically read. It is a novella, some 120 pages, but within that The Empress of Salt and Fortune delivers a tightly packed punch. It is a feminist tale in a Chinese-inspired fantasy world, told through the eyes of a handmaiden, who would‚Äîin most fantasy tales‚Äîbe a "side character."

Through this uniqu

I think I've never read a book quite like this one. There is something in the writing and the way the story progressively unfolds that makes it unique and mysterious. It's a bit like a tale slowly shared as the memories are triggered by echoes from a past deeply cherished.
Remembering the past is of utmost importance, but when the time comes, we must let it go, knowing that after sharing it, it's no longer only ours to carry on.

610. The Hobbit = There and Back Again, J.R.R. Tolkien

The Hobbit, or There and Back Again is a fantasy novel by English author J. R. R. Tolkien. It was published on 21 September 1937 to wide critical acclaim, being nominated for the Carnegie Medal and awarded a prize from the New York Herald Tribune for best juvenile fiction. The book remains popular and is recognized as a classic in children's literature.

We listened to it together and it is definitely a book which comes alive in the audio version. I can just imagine J.R.R. reading it to his own children, puffing on his pipe and savoring the musical combination of rhyme and alliteration in the dwarf‚Äôs names: Dwalin and Balin, Kili and

My husband likes to refer to me as a Hobbit and I retaliate by calling him Sasquatch. After reading this book I have decided that his attempt at an insult (short with hairy feet) is more of a compliment. Hobbits are intelligent, strong-willed, kind and full of heart. They are also chock-full of flaws and weaknesses but are able to recognize them in themselves. They use their inner strength powered by a streak of stubbornness to push on through obstacles and complete whatever task is at hand.

It had been about 10 years since I last read The Hobbit, so I thought I'd give it another go. I am once again amazed and enthralled by this lovely story. I remembered it being enjoyable, but the nobility and strength and development of Bilbo is profound. Tolkien wrote heroes better than anyone. His heroes were flawed without being evil. They were weak without being sniveling or conniving. He truly mastered the art of virtue through story like no one else.

I read this when I was a pre-teen and was enthralled by such a made-up world. Such a classic and it is still captivating.

This story has so many wonderful elements. I can‚Äôt wait until it is assigned to my niece in school and we can read it together and talk about it.

Whether or not readers love the story, it would be difficult not to remember Gandalf, Bilbo and Smeagol.

I have only seen the first film made of this book, but it did help me to imagine everything that was going on here well. Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone is a fantasy novel written by British author J. K. Rowling. It is the first novel in the Harry Potter series and Rowling's debut novel, first published in 1997 by Bloomsbury. It was published in the United States as Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone by Scholastic Corporation in 1998.

This book was as enchanting as it was to 11 year old me when my sister put Harry Potter and the Philosophers Stone in my hands and told me I simply have to read this series.

Harry Potter meant so much to me as a kid as it did to millions of others. It was a magical world I could fall into and experience Harry's amazing adventures with him. I read them over and over and it took me many years to finally come out of my Harry Potter bubble a

This is where it all began, where we were introduced to Harry Potter, Rowling's magical world, a series of exciting adventures and the excellent characters and environments she has given to English literature. It set the standard for contemporary fantasy. Rowling make full use of classic literary and mythological references, freeing herself from the confines of the merely topical, while giving it all a daring sense of newness. This series will live forever.

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone is a fantasy novel written by British author J. K. Rowling. It is the first novel in the Harry Potter series and Rowling's debut novel, first published in 1997 by Bloomsbury. It was published in the United States as Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone by Scholastic Corporation in 1998.

So what is Harry Potter and The Philosopher‚Äôs Stone?

Good question. But first I ask you, what is magic?

To me, magic is the captivating voice of the imagination, transmutable and quantifiable, it finds its verve in the proper arrangement of words. These words can make you laugh, and cry, and dream dreams that will never die.

review_text:
In this science fiction book Earth is at war with the "Buggers" an insect-like alien species that has attacked Earth several times.



Ender Wiggins is a brilliant six-year-old boy with a sadistic older brother Peter, a loving sister Valentine, and parents embarrassed to have three children in a society where two is the norm.



Ender is given the opportunity to attend Battle Academy, a space-based school where children are groomed to be military officers in the war against the Buggers. Though Academy s
I'm not giving any of my money to a man that wrote this, and who regularly donates money that he's earned from his books towards anti-gay rights outlets.

I believe it was A. E. Van Vogt who said, "The Golden Age of Science Fiction is 14." And in fact, much of the classic science fiction of Heinlein and others feed into the mind of the adolescent boy. The protagonist Ender is an adolescent's dream. He is alone, alienated and feels he is not appreciated for how special he is. In other words, he is the average teen male or at least how the average teen male sees himself. Add on the naive and egotistical worldview envisioned by Heinlein and it is no

I enjoyed this a lot more than what I thought I would. I'm hesitant to pick up one of the sequels because they have such mixed reviews but I really want to see what happens next so I'm going for it eventually!

I first read Ender's Game the same year it was published; I was a marginally successful junior in a US Service Academy at the time, and well on my way to forming my current negative opinion about how such works. What ever other critiques readers might have about Card's story here, IMHO he nailed the military training environment, complete with psychological manipulation and Machiavellian intrigue. I am not surprised to hear rumors that Ender's Game might even be promoted by the military training

Every now and then you come across a book whose prose is thoroughly unimpressive but whose premise and sheer bravado manage to suck you in nonetheless, to the point where you end up enjoying it an awful lot. Ender's Game falls into that category for me. The first few chapters feature some of the choppiest prose I've come across in a published book -- sentences so short and dull that I seriously wondered how the book had ever got published. However, the writing gradually gets better, and as for t

The best books are those that make you think and wonder. Even when you finish them, you may not be certain of what they are entirely about. Science fiction often boldly takes us to places no one has gone before and Ender‚Äôs Game does just that. Although the main character is a child and most of the characters too are children, don‚Äôt make the mistake of believing it‚Äôs a YA novel. It isn‚Äôt.

An SF novel with surprising depth - it's astonishing how such a self-declared bigot like Orson Scott Card could have written it. War, paranoia, dehumanisation of the enemy, desensitisation of the soldier... all are captured in the story of Andrew ("Ender") Wiggins, the socially backward boy genius. His expertise is in playing video games. Ultimately, war is only a game, isn't it?

Published in 1985, I am probably one of the few science fiction enthusiasts that had not read this book before now. On the surface, it is a story of a child genius, cultivated by adults to lead a war to save humans from extraterrestrial invaders. It has many deeper levels, such as self-discovery, learning how to face the consequences of decisions, and the damage inflicted by war, particularly on an ethical individual called upon to kill.

As I began reading this, I wondered why they had not made a film adaptation of Ender Wiggins and his strategic genius. By the time I was halfway, I realized that the depth of his character and the internal struggles he faced could never be better illustrated that with Orson's prose. This book had come up on various "Sci-Fi Top Ten" lists, and now I know why.

I know a teen-aged boy who has read this book several times and now I understand why. I appreciate the character development, action, and twist ending in this carefully-plotted YA science fiction. Card speaks to the heart of the issues of growing up through Ender. His portrayals of Valentine and Peter are realistic.

I read this many years ago when a friend strongly recommended it. I have now re-read Ender's Game a number of times and loved it a little bit more every time. It will always have a solid place on my favourites list and I highly recommend it to everyone. Brilliant!

3.5 to 4 stars. This review took a while, because I needed some time to get my thoughts together. This one was definitely a tough one for me to rate. I didn't like it as much as I thought I would, but at the same time I'm pretty sure I liked it more than I should. Not really sure if I'm making any sense at all.

Perhaps it had to do with not knowing anything about this book before I picked it up, other than that it's widely popular and highly acclaimed...which was probably why I felt a little like

I read this book slowly for two reasons: one, life got in the way, often enough I was forced to read a page or two a night, and two, like an observant, language-less bugger, I wanted to watch and really get to know Ender. How this boy genius a reluctant, killing machine becomes and unravels. I loved that he was undefeated, courageous, struggling with his own humanity between kindness and cruelty. I also liked Scott Card's storytelling. Like the lights on the battlefield, he left enough to make y

I am revisiting the review I wrote for this book seven years after I first read it. Ender's Game remains one of the best constructed stories I've read. I, however, have come across the author's real-life doings, as many other readers have. He's not nice. He's a bigot and a homophobe, pushing an agenda I simply cannot agree with. On top of everything, I understand that he's a fervent Mormon. None of these choices sit well with me, and I am confused at what I'm supposed to do with this new informa

As I stated in one of my status updates ~ I had never planned to read this book, I never wanted to give money to a man who I so viscerally disagreed with, I never wanted to promote a person who I would politely refer to as a vile and despicable human being. BUT my son had to read this for school so I grabbed it after he read it just to find out what all the fuss was about.

It was REALLY hard to separate the author from the novel but when I was able to do that I loved this book. I mean I really lo

It plays upon every 14-year-old's desire to be special in a universal way. I think it has the same appeal as Ayn Rand to 14 year old boys: it presents a powerful character that you are supposed to identify with who defeats all odds, mostly alone. I read an interview with Michael Moorcock in which he talked about this being a problem with the canon of western literature since Odysseus. The hero characters in our current myths (e.g. Ender's Game) set up inhuman values and feats that leave us feeli

For readers skeptical of the potency of science fiction, this is the book you must read to open your eyes. Consider its publication date as you read and realize that Card pre-visualized the Internet, blogging, and the fact that (to paraphrase the New Yorker) on the Web, no one knows you're a megalomaniacal fifteen-year old.

A Game of Thrones (A Song of Ice and Fire, #1), George R.R. Martin

A Game of Thrones is the first novel in A Song of Ice and Fire, a series of fantasy novels by American author George R. R. Martin. It was first published on August 1, 1996. The novel won the 1997 Locus Award and was nominated for both the 1997 Nebula Award and the 1997 World Fantasy Award. The novella Blood of the Dragon, comprising the Daenerys Targaryen chapters from the novel, won the 1997 Hugo Award for Best Novella. In Janua

I want to give A game of Thrones five stars, but alas, I cannot. It is a fantastic epic tale with engaging heroes, and nasty villains that one would enjoy to slap silly. I found myself emotionally invested in the fate of the Stark family. Unfortunately, the book contains some glaring problems.

By now everyone heard of Game of Thrones. HBO did a wonderful job at adapting the mammoth books George R.R. Martin wrote, yet I feel that, in many regards, the books still hold the upper hand over the TV show.

The story takes place in Westeros, where noble families fight for the Iron Throne from where the Seven Kingdoms are ruled. The book follows multiple viewpoints, as the dynastic fight grows fiercer and intrigues and subplots are sown into a great epic.

I heard a lot of people comparing Martin

Game of Thrones is to high fantasy as The Sopranos was to crime fiction: a charismatic, mesmerizing opera filled with violence and intrigue and was simply fun to follow.

HBO may be the basis of my comparison but it is by no means exclusive of all that is right with this book (and presumably the series). And full disclaimer, I only watched a handful of Sopranos episodes and am yet to watch my first GOT show.

A Game of Thrones is really good. I liken it to Tolstoy's Anna Karenina in that it's a sweeping epic mostly focused on the movers and shakers while keeping the timeline linear by shifting the focus back and forth between characters and groups of characters, specifically families.

The world kept screaming at me that this book is one of the best fantasy novels ever. So I bought it (and scored an awesome 1990s cover). Then people started warning me how complicated it was. So I let it collect dust on my bookshelves for a couple years. Until now.

I didn‚Äôt find it difficult to follow. Sure, I had to flip back a few times to recall characters and events. That is to be expected in a long book with multiple points of view. I do wish Martin had stuck to one name per character. But,

Long winded doesn't even begin to describe George R. R. Martin's writing style. Nothing I can say about this book will be a revelation to anyone who has read it. It should have been at least 25% slimmer. I fear the book itself would've been a thousand or more words shorter had just the term 'bastard' been omitted. I loved it!!!! If you are a fantasy lover drop whatever it is you are reading and start this book series...
He is definitely the master of Fantasy...

I refuse to write a review for one of the best books ever written. Asking a serious fantasy fan to write a review for Lord of the Rings is like asking a Christian to write a review for The Bible.
So instead I will supply you with this graph:

Authors who inspire a movement are usually misunderstood, especially by those they have inspired, and Tolkien is no exception, but one of the biggest misconceptions about Tolkien is the idea that he is somehow an 'innovator of fantasy'. He did add a number of techniques to the repertoire of epic fantasy writers, and these have been dutifully followed by his many imitators, but for the most part, these techniques are little more than bad habits.

I am sorry to say, I can't finish this book. I always forget the uncanny power Tolkien's writing has to depress my mood--and the oddest part is, I don't even know why. I'm sure he was a wonderful person, I KNOW he was a great storyteller; but there's something about the way he writes that just plain messes with my mind. It's . . . uncanny, like I said.

Oh, well. All you Tolkienites out there will just have to forgive me.

SF. I've been putting off reading this for a very long time as I was scared of it not being wonderful. It's such a big part of geek culture; what if I thought it was dumb?! But it wasn't. It was wonderful. It's like Monty Python and Kurt Vonnegut melted together and spread on toast -- crisp and tangy and a little bit ridiculous. The science fiction plot is paper-thin and kind of random, but this book gave me some really good laughs. I about lost it when the computer on their space ship started singing "You'll Never Walk Alone" while the missiles closed in. I was reminded of this novel when I was reading one of the books in Terry Pratchett's Discworld series, which is pretty much the same sort of thing, except in a fantasy world rather than SF. Anyway: read for laughs.

But I can't do that because I rarely drink to excess, and by unlucky happenstance, those rare moments have never coincided with the completion of a book. Go figure.

This just might be the most over-rated book ever. Don't get me wrong; I liked it and thought it was funny. Clever and funny, in fact. But that's all it was.
A surprisingly large number of people seem to think this is The Greatest Book Ever Written, or something close to it. In fact, it's funny at a high school level (meaning rather puerile), and clever only in its use of absurdity, but Adams doesn't really have anything deep or important to say. After all these years, I'm proud to say I'm finally a woman who knows where her towel is.

This book should get 4 1/2 stars, but that's not an option here. It's been around forever, but I always ignored it because I don't generally like sci-fi. I gave it a try because it's in "1001 Books."
What a treat! Silly, smart, satirical, and just a good healthy overdose of pure fun. Can't wait to read it again, which is saying a lot. I rarely re-read books, but this one will make a great traveling companion

Times have changed a lot since this book was published & the original radio series was broadcast. While there are echoes of Doctor Who & Red Dwarf, to me the Hitch hiker books have a lot more in common with Alice in Wonderland than modern science fiction. There is a feeling that the whole world is askew - oops, sorry universe! A great cast of characters with really witty dialogue. Marvin the Paranoid Android will always hold a special place in my heart!

What can I tell about the book? Other than that one has to read to experience the kinky hilarity, the improbability which almost seems probable, especially the fact that mice are a more evolved species than homo sapiens, the crash course to the galaxy offered by the Hitchhikers guide and the various hilarious strangely named characters, Arthur Dent, the only earthling being the sanest amongst them all. I found my soul mate in Marvin, the permanently depressed robot. We both have the same favouri

While reading, I tried to keep track of all of the references I never understood in my life because I hadn't yet read this book. Here's the list:

- The answer is 42
- Mostly harmless
- Don't panic
- Knowing where your towel is
- The Restaurant at the End of the Universe (this is a conference room at Goodreads HQ and I never even wondered about it)
- So long, and thanks for all the fish

Overall, I enjoyed but didn't lose my shit over this book. Maybe I'll "get it" one day.

Science fiction is not everyone's cup of tea even of students of science so it is difficult to write a good and engaging science fiction. This first book in a long series seems to one of the rare kinds.

The book gets technical and expansive in the field of astronomical science but can at the same time remain humorous.

But this book is clearly not that good as the world seems to make of it. It can be an enjoyable read for one time but it is in no terms a genius work.

Well The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is a bit different than what I've read so far. There are ideas and strange ways of looking at life, disguised as jokes, which really captivated me. But some of the remarks and jokes of the book were very much based on American and English culture which left me baffled sometimes. Give it a try if you wanna read sth fun and different.

Not my cup of tea. I didn't enjoy this book at all. I'm not the biggest fan of Sci-fi to begin with and this plotless nonsensical book didn't really help my case. I was confused most of the time, rolled my eyes at its supposedly "witty" prose, and bored myself to death as I tried to get through it. I seriously wonder why this book is so highly acclaimed?

The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy is probably the most entertaining, the most whimsical, and the funniest book that I've ever read. It tells the story of Arthur Dent who wakes up to find that his house is about to be demolished for the construction of a bypass. What he doesn't know is that at the same time the Earth is also being prepared for demolition, ironically for the construction of an intergalactic bypass. With the help of his friend Ford Prefect, who turns out to be an alien himself,

This novel is funny and fun at the same time--5 stars for the audiobook that I listened to some years ago, and 4 stars for the print book (some things are just so much funnier out loud). This time I'm going to read ALL of the books, not just the first two the way I did last time due to a lack of enough audiobooks at my library. However, one of my kids came home with an omnibus and I can easily read one a day while she's out. She'd have been none the wiser, but the cover isn't lying totally flat

The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is one of the most peculiar, unexpected and fun books you will ever read!

Douglas Adams combines (and succeeds) a little bit of physics, mathematics and simple ordinary life to explain to us the unknown - to humankind - universe and its spectacles!

And the simple life is that of Arthur Dent and the time is a very unlucky Thursday in the meadows of England. Along with Ford Prefect (an alien), Trillian (a fellow humanoid), Zaphod Beeblebrox (the President) and Ma

Science fiction filled with satire, tongue-in-cheek humor, intelligence, creativity, philosophy, and quirkiness. Loved how the alternate life forms showed the same foibles as the humans. I found it entertaining, enjoyable, and extremely clever. The version I read contained extra material about how the movie came to be made, along with interviews of the actors and script-writer. Can‚Äôt believe I had not read this before now. A must read for fans of science fiction.

An unequivocal piece of genius, and one of the best literary works of the modern age. This book is excellent evidence that comedy can be dark without being gory or violent. And that deep, meaningful questions can be explored without being too serious or melancholy.
If there is a library in heaven, I hope this is the first book in the Science Fiction section.
Forever a fave. Enjoyed listening to the audio book this time around.
One of the best, most ingenious, books of all time!
I hated this book. I would never recommend this book to anyone. I was so lost, the whole book was confusing and random. 1/5 stars

I grew up wearing black, watching horror movies, reading OTT fantasy. Comedy was just never on my radar, I detested sitcoms (The Office and B99 changed that later on), never laughed at bro-movies, thought standup was lame, and never appreciated a knock-knock joke.

Then I read Hitchhiker's and I couldn't stop smiling but I also couldn't stop thinking. I love how intelligent and wonderful Adams is. I wanna hang with them, party with him, just sit quietly and smile at everythi

I understand why this book has such a large fanbase. I can see that it's clever. I can see that it's unique. There were many parts in it that I found slightly amusing.

But it doesn't change the fact that in my opinion, space is unquestionably, unconditionally, positively BORING. I would have given the book two stars, but I gave it three just for being one of the few space books I have read that hasn't made me fall asleep before I made it through the first chapter.

I once played in a band, the way you do. It was a long time ago.

On Monday evenings, we would end our practice early, brew fresh coffee, switch on the radio and gather 'round to listen to a radio play written by some bloke none of us had heard of. It was love at first ear.

I miss that bloke and I miss my mate Paul who introduced him to me and went to the same beyond.

I hope you've made friends up there.

Three readings of this tongue in cheek space opera all lead to one inescapable conclusion: it's just not that funny. Not to say that it's completely unfunny; it's amusing at times, but the jokes are foreshadowed, then strung out at great length and beaten repeatedly, over and over. However, there are certain Science Fiction books that must be read in order to fully appreciate the genre and to understand the inside jokes and references of its fans; this is one of those books.

I thought this book was really funny and enjoyable. The characters were all very unique and distinct, which I always like to see in a book. My only issue with it was that it felt like it should be longer. The end didn't seem really climatic, it just sort of ended for no reason. But other than that, I really liked it.

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, J.K. Rowling

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, is a fantasy novel written by British author J.K. Rowling, and the second novel in the Harry Potter series.

The plot follows Harry's second year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, during which a series of messages on the walls of the school's corridors warn that the "Chamber of Secrets" has been opened and that the "heir of Slytherin" would kill all pupils who do not come from all-magical f

I am always surprised by J.K. Rowling's ability to make her books an allegory of our modern world and it's big and hideous problems. We all know, after all, that she covered discrimination, wars, hate crime, the Kardashians, etc.

Let's take this book for example. Harry goes back to Hogwarts. Now enter Gilderoy Lockhart. A fame enamored charlatan, who knows nothing about anything, except memory spells. So clearly a Kardashian. Now some might ask: do Kardashians know memory spells. And the answer i
I read this all in one 8 hour sitting... I need a life

Overall, I loved this, and I can't wait to start Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban today.

Wow, the Dursleys were even more loathsome in this book than the first.
I love the Weasleys even more than I already did.
I am so glad my mother never sent me a Howler.

What was once trite and commonplace is now daring and new, and vice versa. It just happens to look like Cervantes's masterpiece.

Dune.

No other single syllable means as much to the science fiction genre, a single word that conjures images of sandworms, spice wars, great battles between rival dynastic families and a massively detailed and intricately crafted universe. No wonder this is widely regarded as not just a Science Fiction masterpiece, but a literary achievement as well.

Like a study of Shakespeare, the reader finds that this is an archetype upon which many influences and imitators have based their works. The comple

If this is the gold standard against which all science fiction must measure and be judged, let's just blow our brains out right now and call it a day.

As far as I can tell, Dune largely inspires two points of view. One marvels at its historical importance and world-building (unique, fascinating, complex, rich), and the other dislikes the stilted writing but does so apologetically because Frank Herbert couldn't help the fact that he wrote science fiction in the 1960s and that Edward Said hadn't d

People often forget that this series is what innovated our modern concept of science fiction (up until Neuromancer and The Martix, at least). Dune took the Space Opera and asked if it might be more than spandex, dildo-shaped rockets, and scantily-clad green women. Herbert created a vast and complex system of ancient spatial politics and peoples, then set them at one another's throats over land, money, and drugs.

Dune is often said to relate to Sci Fi in the same way that Tolkien relates to Fantas

Welcome to Unpopular Review Time! Where I go against what almost everyone else says about a book.

Before we start, please do not be fooled by the three star rating. Even if I didn't like really like the book, I have to acknowledge there are reasons why Dune is a cornerstone of the Sci Fi genre.

Now, let's talk about the important stuff.

This is a masterpiece of world building.

We get a new planet, and while it's obvious that Herbert based his desert planet on real sights and cultures, it's still aw

Epic and highly inventive, but not nearly as great as I remember it being. I think Herbert's writing really gets in the way of the story. He continuously tells the reader what each character is thinking through italicized internal dialogue. Sometimes uses the third person narration to do the same thing in a more elegant way. The problem is that he does both, often times for the same character in the same paragraph. It's super clunky, and took me out of the story every time.

Mostly riveting! In general, I think I loved it?

The worldbuilding is still legendary here, all these years later. I'm going to leave the issues alone (Obviously, there are issues. 1965 was a long time ago).

Mostly, I can see why this book is a beloved classic and why it's been so inspirational. It's a wild ride, interweaving a lot of cool threads, with so much to say about so many dimensions of human life in the possible future. Really cool overall. And the worms are awesome.

Dune is a 1965 science fiction novel by American author Frank Herbert. In the far future, humanity has eschewed advanced computers due to a religious prohibition, in favor of adapting their minds to be capable of extremely complex tasks. Much of this is enabled by the spice melange, which is found only on Arrakis, a desert planet with giant sand-worms as its most notable native life-form.

Filled with politics and religion, and the politics of religion, Dune follows House Atreides' new rule over the spice-drug producing planet of Arrakis.

Whispers begin to spread of the legend of an off-world prophet that was long ago chiseled into the minds of a people. And the people have a mind of their own.

Frank Herbert's science fiction novel 'Dune', first printed in 1965, is the first in his six-book series (there are books after the first six in the series, written by the author's son Brian Herbert and other collaborators after Frank Herbert's death). The six books primarily follow the aristocrat Atreides family through several generations (in fact, millennia - I read all six Frank H. books years ago). I loved them, but I was only a YA at the time. I wasn't sure I would still like them today. G

Dune is a beautiful and complex fiction masterpiece. Frank Herbert built up an incredibly vivid world, layer upon layer, with multiple religious/belief systems, strongly developed cultures which clashed with each other and a thousand currents of political manoeuvring, from the lowest classes up to the emperor himself.

Dune. A single word that conjures images of sandworms, spice wars, great battles between rival dynastic families and a massively detailed and intricately crafted universe. No wonder this is widely regarded as not just a Science Fiction masterpiece, but a literary achievement as well.

In space, everybody's kind of an asshole.

The young man born with a dark destiny (or perhaps destined to be a savior); space-opera trappings of interplanetary intrigue and warfare; mysterious, mystical warrior/clerics with powers of precognition and controlling others through the power of their voice; etc., etc., (no

Despite the antiquated prose and clunky characterizations, Dune holds up very well with its world building, lore and mysticism.

I finally got around to checking this classic off my list and I'm glad I did, because I now understand why this book is so celebrated. The world that Herbert creates is internally consistent, original, vivid and mysterious. In 600 pages, an interplanetary ecosystem focused on one desert planet blooms in the readers mind full of politics, treachery, indigenous people and

If it's been awhile since you last read the book, I highly recommend this version of the audiobook, which is read by an ensemble cast. There are at least 3 different audio recordings that I know of, and they're also good but this is the best imo.

Ensemble cast readings are my favorite (with the exception of Graphic Audios) because they're usually so well performed that it enhances the story. You get to experience the world and be fully immersed in it as the story unfolds. It really is amazing whe

I feel like the pacing is slow and this is from the 60s when pacing was much slower. It is a book the modern science fiction genre is built on. Despite how slow the story is, I enjoyed this book. The political machinations suck you in. It is sad to see Paul lose his innocence and become so hard. I do think I will read more in this series.

I know that many of you out there haven't gotten around to reading Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban. This is, without a doubt, my favorite Harry Potter novel. It has been my favorite ever since it came out, and it has only improved on rereading. I adore it; I adore the sense of adventure that spills over every page, the expansion of Rowling's magical universe, and the subtle changes that mark the book's passage from children's fiction to more mature young adult.

When I was younger I especially adored the book because it introduced me to other magic societies and international schools of wizardry

Ah yes, friends, this is where, in my humble opinion, this is where the legend of Harry Potter really takes off. There are so many things I love about this book: the Quidditch World Cup, the Tri-Wizard Tournament, the Yule Ball, Mad-Eye, more Sirius, etc.

But what I really love about this one is how it kind of serves as a bridge between the shorter, more young-adultish, magical fantasy wonder of the first three books and the final three. Things get a little darker here, the story has more layers

If the "shit got real" in the last book, well, in this fourth book shit got unreal.

Goblet of Fire took the series forward and yet in tone it felt like a regression to the first two books. Certainly it is darker and slightly more mature in subject matter than the first two. However, there's a lingering "freshman" feel which I blame on the inclusion of the Tri Wizard Tournament. It seemed out of place at this point in the story.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Harry Potter #7), J.K. Rowling

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows is a fantasy book written by British author J. K. Rowling, and the seventh and final novel of the Harry Potter series. The book was released on 21 July 2007, ending the series that began in 1997 with the publication of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.

The story follows Harry Potter who has been tasked by Dumbledore with finding and destroying Lord Voldemort's secret to immortality.

(So I never did a review of this and am deciding to add one now.)

I'm a Millennial, and like most Millennials, I grew up with Harry Potter. Not just the books, but we kinda aged with him (or thereabouts). It's a coming of age story for our whole generation, whether or not we received our Hogwarts letters.

And we were there together. We were at midnight release parties and movie theaters, lined up and excited to share in the adventure. I can't think of the number of people who I've bonded with over
I always wonder how the characters are doing after a series endsü§î

I remember when the hardback came out. Wal-Mart was having a big to do at midnight but I worked 3rd shift at the post office at that time. I stopped by after work around 7 ish am and there were a few copies left. I was so excited and I ended up not getting much sleep and was tired that night at work because I couldn't put the book down.

And I cried and cried. I still do. Some of these books do that to me no matter how many times I read the books.

Happy Reading!

I think I've made it quite clear throughout my years on Goodreads how much the Harry Potter series and world means to me, but I have yet to do any kind of review on any of the books. This series means so much to so many people, it gave me friends when I had none, and most importantly, the courage to be myself.

There are so many wonderful things about this series; how detailed the world is, the history, the myriad of different cha

Deathly Hallows is in fierce competition with Half-Blood Prince as the worst book of the series. It is an extremely bloated book in which nothing much happens for chapters upon chapters because Rowling is dragging the storyline out -- so it can end at the end of the school year, like all the other books. Many plotlines of previous books are barely touched upon (S.P.E.W.) or "resolved" in an entirely dissatisfactory manner (Grawp, though I wasn't unhappy about not seeing more of him).

Characters

AND my reread of Harry Potter is over. It was still as wonderful and heartbreaking as the first time that I tackled this world of magic.

If you have never read this series, I suggest that you try to get to it one day. It's a wonderful series to experience magic, amazing creatures, well loved characters and complex plots!
The range of emotions that a reader goes through while reading this is pretty intense.

Bravo, J.K. Rowling, bravo!

4 out of 5 stars for Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, the 5th book in the original 7 book "Harry Potter" young adult fantasy series published in 2003 by J.K. Rowling. I cannot believe this is over 15 years old, as I think about what I want to put in my review. Given it's HP, and everyone does review on it, I'm keeping it short. A few things I loved about this book:

1. Dolores Umbridge is awesome. Awesome as a villain, that is. She brings out the worst in so many p

To give this book (or series) anything less than 5 stars would be a crime, tbh. Rowling is absolutely incredible at storytelling and creating characters with distinct voices. I'm appreciating the world-building a lot more now as well. She crafted it beautifully throughout the series.

- Harry‚Äôs grief was palpable and it hurt. A lot.
- Harry and Cho‚Äôs relationship was boring as hell.
- Dumbledore is my favourite character. He‚Äôs open with his mistakes and the way he came to care and protect Harry w

After I finished reading Sorcerer's Stone, I went on to begin reading Chamber of Secrets. But I stopped that perusal 4 fifths through and without giving myself a reason, launched into reading Order of the Phoenix.

And I'm glad that I did read it. I was having nostalgia about the time where Dumbledore featured prominently. For all purposes, this book could have been called Harry Potter and Albus Dumbledore.

This was the first book to ditch the mystery-like format of previous books. It's a sizable b

This is my favorite installment of the quintessential modern bildungsroman. Nevertheless, it has its problems, familiar to any reader of Rowling's.

She never seems to gain control of her writing, which spirals out into thousand-page doorstops filled with unimportant side characters and rambling plots. The story is moved along by arbitrary plot devices, often magic. Instead of using the magic to make her world seem more strange and wondrous, she uses it to cover up plot holes. Why write a consiste

Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (Harry Potter, #5), J.K. Rowling
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix follows Harry Potter's struggles through his fifth year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, including the surreptitious return of the antagonist Lord Voldemort, O.W.L. exams, and an obstructive Ministry of Magic. The novel was published on 21 June 2003 by Bloomsbury in the United Kingdom.

On this sunny Mother's Day, my middle child suggested that the perfect gift for me would be to finish reading Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix outside, aloud to her. We've been reading book #5 at night, one chapter at a time, and the mature shift that has taken place in the last few chapters, into violence and loss, has been peppering her sleep lately

Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (Harry Potter #6), J.K. Rowling

Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince is a fantasy novel written by British author J. K. Rowling and the sixth and penultimate novel in the Harry Potter series.

Set during protagonist Harry Potter's sixth year at Hogwarts, the novel explores the past of Harry's nemesis, Lord Voldemort, and Harry's preparations for the final battle against Voldemort alongside his headmaster and mentor Albus Dumbledore.

I was forced into watching Mockingjay: Part II this weekend. To clarify, I watched the second part of the last Hunger Games movie without having read any of the books, without having watched any of the movies.

Needless to say, I was confused as fuck.

So many questions and thoughts ran through my mind as I watched the movie. Why is Peeta so thin? Did that huge-ass bruise really disappear from her neck the next day? Is Katniss supposed to look like she's about to burst into tears at any given moment

My "Epic Book Recipe" Checklist for The Hunger Games:

1. A sharp and intelligent heroine with just the right amount of emotion who gives in to absolutely nothing and no one?

2. A sweet and sensitive hero who loves and supports the heroine unconditionally?

3. An original setting with a unique and thrilling plot?

4. A couple of earth-shattering shocks every now and then to keep the readers' mind reeling?

5. Extraordinary side characters from interesting backgrounds who possess the much-needed Voic

Notes: A Pax Romana parallel, where odds are ever mostly misses, and games of guise, of glossy lies, mean existential kisses.

Suzanne Collins has balls ovaries of steel to make us willingly cheer for a teenage girl to kill other children. In a YA book.
Two reasons why this book rocks: (a) It is not Twilight, and (b) I really hate reality shows.

Seriously, how long would it take for reality shows to evolve from "Survivor" to "Hunger Games"?

Yes, this book is full of imperfections. It often requires a strenuous suspension of disbelief. It can cause a painful amount of eye-rolling and shaking fist at the book pages.

A lot of things are troubling me about The Hunger Games. A lot of things which I more and more perceive and which are not solely connected with this book but with the metaphor behind the words. People attach themselves to fictional freedom without seeing what really something is and which unfortunately is here to stay because you can't wake a person who is pretending to be asleep. You can‚Äôt make a shift on a deeper level, if the only thing that attracts you to this book is ‚Äì a vision of fight, r

If I were a teenager or recommending this to a teen, I might give it 3*; as an adult, I give it 2*.

PLOT

It's a potentially exciting but gruesome story, but most of the characters were rather flat, much of the plot was predictable (it's not hugely original; in particular, it is VERY similar to the Japanese "Battle Royale"), and there were too many flaws in the plot. I fail to understand its very high ratings.

5 stars to Suzanne Collins's The Hunger Games. Such a popular series, so many people have read it or watched the movies... do I really need to do a review? But since I've put it in my top 20 favorite books, isn't there an obligation to review it?

YES

Let's make it simple... it may be young adult, and it may be fantasy, but neither of those facts matter when you have a set of richly flawed characters, a plot that is an absolute play on "survival of the fittest" and imagery so vivid it jumps off

Clearly, some books just never get old. By now I know The Hunger Games almost by heart, but it still manages to stir me in all the good/bad ways. I can't tell what exactly it is that works so well - the absolutely perfect pacing, the heart, Katniss' unforgettable voice or her love for Prim and Rue, or Peeta's kindness. Whatever it is, this book keeps me in thrall every time and makes me forget about the ultimately shoddy dystopian premise.
